headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Matt. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from manag
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Matt. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as the risk factors associated with our business and our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC because these risk factors may affect our operations and financial results. 
In today's release and on today's call, we provide both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results. We provide this supplemental information to enable investors to perform additional comparisons of operating results and to analyze financial performance without the impact of certain noncash expenses or other items that may obscure trends in our underlying performance. 
During our call, our comments and comparisons to income statement items will be based primarily on non-GAAP results. For a complete reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures, please refer to our earnings release issued earlier today, available on our website, www.qorvo.com, under investors. [Operator Instructions] .
Sitting with me today are Bob Bruggeworth, President and CEO; Steve Buhaly, Chief Financial Officer; Eric Creviston, President of Qorvo's Mobile Products Group; James Klein, President of Qorvo's Infrastructure and Defense Products Group. I'm also joined by other members of Qorvo's management team. 
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call. Revenue in the December quarter was approximately $620 million consistent with our preannouncement issued January 7. Gross margin and operating margin fell i
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call. 
Revenue in the December quarter was approximately $620 million consistent with our preannouncement issued January 7. Gross margin and operating margin fell in at 47.9% and 25.3%, respectively. Operating expenses were down sequentially, reflecting less variable compensation expense and seasonally lower spending. Orval generated approximately $156.5 million in free cash flow and repurchased $250 million of stock to enhance shareholder value. 
In Infrastructure and Defense, revenue increased sequentially, with improved performance in wireless infrastructure. We expect this business to recover further in the near term, reinforcing our top line growth opportunities in calendar are 2016. 
Our IDP team continues to sharpen its focus on the highest growth segments into diversified business portfolio. This focus drives alignment with the growth markets of the Internet of Things, connected home, connected car, and the high growth segments within aerospace and defense. By leveraging Qorvo's comprehensive product and technology portfolio, we are providing customers highly differentiated solutions, especially exciting in the growth rate of gain solutions and in many of IDP's key market segments, driving a compound annual growth rate of approximately 25% for the next few years. 
We expect growth rates in 2016 to be well above IDP's underlying markets and significantly above the legacy growth rates of our premerger multimarket organizations. 
In mobile, the increase in global demand for broadband data and always-on connectivity continues to trigger a dramatic increase in the requirements for mobile networks and connected devices. For smartphone manufacturers and network operators, it's become increasingly difficult to capitalize on this demand while also solving your challenges related to frequency crowding, as carriers' signals are aggregated, distinct bands and protocols are operated in narrowly adjacent frequency bands and popular new consumer applications increase the congestion on our networks. 
For all these reasons, it's increasingly clear that the most effective solutions available to network operators and device manufacturers are better-performing, more highly integrated RF solutions. In fact, if you were to examine the product designs in development for those networks and devices, you'd identify increasing requirement for world-class filters, switchers, tuners and amplifiers, all tightly packaged and system-level implementations. This is tilting the competitive playing field in Qorvo's favor. Said another way, the RF suppliers with today's best performing, most tightly integrated solutions are at the forefront of the most challenging and most lucrative customer designs. This year, next year and extending well into 2018. 
As customers increasingly require more tightly integrated, high-performance system-level solutions, this is favoring Qorvo's comprehensive portfolio of premium products. In fact, this is why we became Qorvo. 
Now, one year into the creation of Qorvo, the roughly 7,000 members of the Qorvo team have much to be proud of. Looking at our first full year, compared to calendar 2014, revenue grew 12%. Gross margin expanded more than 400 basis points and operating income increased more than 40%. In fact, the non-GAAP earnings we reported over the last 4 quarters equates to a little over $4.60 per share based on our Q3 share count of approximately 144 million shares. 
On the design front, Orval is growing our dollar content in the most highly anticipated marquee smartphones launching this year at our 3 largest mobile customers. 
It's worth pointing out that in December, we released the industry's first 6-inch [indiscernible] wafers in our Florida fab, qualified 6-inch SAW wafers in our Greensboro fab and demonstrated our first 8-inch BAW wafers in our Texas fab. 
We can't overstate how important these achievements are. We see our 6-inch SAW capacity contributing to growth and profitability in the current year. And we see our 8-inch BAW capacity doing the same in 2017. 
We commenced shipments of our recently launched BAW-based quadplexers for FDD bands 1 and 3, an industry first, and we demonstrated BAW-based hexaplexer prototypes. We've also been selected to support a number of key cellular platforms with our next-generation auto tracking agreement. We commenced production shipments in support of a large global smartphone OEM and it's landed a number of large tailwinds later this year. We've also recently expanded our shipments of the antenna control solutions into the China smartphone market. Previously, Qorvo's antenna tuners and tuners have been highly concentrated within a small number of high-volume marquee devices. So we're thrilled with the increasing our addressable market in China as these customers add our functionality to support their standing presence in the worldwide market. 
In IDP, December was an exceptionally strong design win quarter. Here are some of the highlights: We captured multiple key design wins for macro and small cell based station applications, we believe network capacity constraints will accelerate the adoption of small cell base station and massive MIMO active antenna. 
Massive MIMO active antenna systems are driving a 10x increase in RF content and next-generation base stations. We continue to work on capturing new design wins as the market shifts from 4G LTE to LTEA, LTE Pro and eventually, 5G. 
At this year's Consumer Electronics Show, we supplied a suite of critical megalith components for a 5G massive MIMO demonstration performed by a leading base station OEM. The demo featured Qorvo space shifters, power amplifiers and switches. 
We also expanded our presence in the connected home with key design wins and gateways and access points highlighted by our design wins and flagship products at both NetGear and Lync Sys. 
We continue to believe that the rapidly increasing number of connected devices represented by the Internet of Things will be IDP's largest growth engine. In defense, we are a market leader in GaN and we continue to experience strong growth with our GaN-based products. 
For example, we secured a multi-year win on a next-generation electronic warfare system using our patented station solid-state RF technology with GaN [indiscernible] with hundreds of system installation anticipated over the life of the contract. On a synergy front, we continue to be on target to achieve our goals, the largest of which includes the increase in sourcing of margin assembly, and increased in sourcing of SAW filters. So for Qorvo, across all our businesses, we believe industry fundamentals remain strong. 
We are leveraging our comprehensive product portfolio of world-class RF solutions, rapidly introducing new products and technologies, expanding into new serviceable markets and enjoying very favorable design win activity. We are growing our dollar content and our 3 largest mobile customers in the most highly anticipated marquee smartphones being released this year. And we anticipate strong growth in IDP. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Steve for a more detailed look at our financials.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. In the December quarter, Qorvo's revenue decreased 12% sequentially to $620 million. The Mobile Products revenue declined 15% to $489 million due to lower customer demand for existing business we'd already won. In IDP, revenue grew slightly t
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. In the December quarter, Qorvo's revenue decreased 12% sequentially to $620 million. The Mobile Products revenue declined 15% to $489 million due to lower customer demand for existing business we'd already won. In IDP, revenue grew slightly to $130 million. Qorvo had two 10% customers, the larger at approximately 42% of revenue, representing the aggregated demand of multiple subcontractors for the second customer. 
Our second 10% customer during the quarter was Huawei. Gross margin was 47.9%, down sequentially from 49.7%. The sequential decline reflects the lower yields in inventory adjustments. 
Operating expenses were approximately $140 million for the December quarter, down $17 million sequentially. The decline was driven by reduced accruals and bonus expense and seasonally lower spending. 
Operating income was $156.9 million or just over 25% of revenue. Net income for the December quarter was $148 million or $1.03 per diluted share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Total cash and investments are over $1 billion and cash flow from operations totaled $218 million. CapEx was $62 million, primarily to address growth in demand for our premium filters. Finally, the company repurchased approximately 4.6 million shares at a total cost of $250 million and has $750 million remaining in its share repurchase program. 
We're proud of Qorvo's first full year performance and excited about the opportunities in the coming year. We're introducing an expanded set of new products, combining switches and filters and leveraging our broad set of competencies, including BAW filter and gallium nitrite process technologies. All of this is creating exciting new growth opportunities for Qorvo. 
With the first full year of Qorvo now in the books, I'm pleased to report the company exceeded its targets or achievement of an exit run rate of $75 million in synergies and is on track for the previously committed $150 million of run rate reduction by the end of calendar 2016. The largest remaining task is migration of all mobile segment parts in the company's China-based assembly and test facilities. 
Now let's turn to our business outlook. Qorvo currently believes demand environment and its end market supports the following non-GAAP expectations for the quarter ending April 2: quarterly revenue of approximately $600 million; gross margin of about 50%; net interest expense of about $15 million; tax rate at approximately 3%; and diluted earnings per share of $0.90 to $0.95 based on approximately 142 million shares. Our March revenue expectations are slightly below our preannouncement, reflecting an overall conservative posture in a cautious environment as well as the timing of new product ramps. 
We think Calendar 2016 will be a strong year for Qorvo. During which we'll continue to make progress on our target operating model while building a robust and defensible technology mode. Actual quarterly results may differ from these expectations and as such -- and such differences may be material. We currently expect to report March quarter results on May 4. 
Now on a personal note, I'm turning 60 at the end of this year and I've always had, as a personal goal, to retire by that point. But at December also, fortuitously, marks the end of our second year as Qorvo, and I'm proud to say we're on track to achieve the goals we've set for our first 2-year period. It's been a pleasure being part of Qorvo and in helping to shape its course. The company's on a fantastic trajectory, and I'm really looking forward to helping with the transition to a new CFO and participating in the company's success over the balance of the year before moving on to more personal pursuits. 
With that, I'm going to hand the call back to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Before opening the call to questions, I want to take a moment to thank Steve for the invaluable role he's played in creating Qorvo. Steve has been instrumental in shaping our organization. He's now put Qorvo on a very solid financial footin
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Before opening the call to questions, I want to take a moment to thank Steve for the invaluable role he's played in creating Qorvo. Steve has been instrumental in shaping our organization. He's now put Qorvo on a very solid financial footing and he's assembled an outstanding financial organization. The entire Qorvo team is stronger as a result of his contribution, and we are all very happy for him as he looks to spend more time with his family and friends. Until then, he'll play a major role in the selection of successor and will continue to serve as Qorvo's CFO while the transition to his successor is completed. 
And with that, operator, we will now take questions.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take the first question from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take the first question from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, when i look at your implied fiscal '16 sales growth, it was modest, and we all know because of the demand weakness around your largest customer, my question is that as we look out to fiscal '17, how fast do you think the total addressable market can
componenttext: Bob, when i look at your implied fiscal '16 sales growth, it was modest, and we all know because of the demand weakness around your largest customer, my question is that as we look out to fiscal '17, how fast do you think the total addressable market can grow? And do you think you can match that growth?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: FY '16, as you pointed out, has been a solid year for us but maybe not as strong as what we have liked but clearly, we had a few headwinds in the infrastructure market, and as you pointed out, we have other large customers. So moving off of that, we are v
componenttext: FY '16, as you pointed out, has been a solid year for us but maybe not as strong as what we have liked but clearly, we had a few headwinds in the infrastructure market, and as you pointed out, we have other large customers. So moving off of that, we are very confident in the IDP business growing significant faster than its underlying markets. James and his team have done a great job of realigning their product portfolio to drive above-industry growth there. So I think you're going to see a very nice rebound in growth beginning, actually, in the beginning of our fiscal '17. As you commented on the [indiscernible] business in the mobile phones business, clearly, we've got a cautious view in the next couple of quarters as we look out in our guidance that we gave for this quarter, along with the beginning of the next fiscal year. With that said, depending on the timing of new program ramps, and our confidence in the wings that we already have in our largest 3 customers, I do believe the second half of FY '17 will be very strong and should be above industry growth rates.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. And maybe Bob, as a follow-up on to that, when you use the word cautious or conservative around demand, is it that your customers are building fewer units than you talked before? Is it a comment on your content at those customers? Is it market shar
componenttext: I see. And maybe Bob, as a follow-up on to that, when you use the word cautious or conservative around demand, is it that your customers are building fewer units than you talked before? Is it a comment on your content at those customers? Is it market share? So what is giving you that caution?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with -- absolutely, customers are building less homes than what we expected just a month ago. Some of that's in demand. I think also for the nodes, we didn't lose any sockets over the last 4 months that changed our outlook for the December qu
componenttext: Let me start with -- absolutely, customers are building less homes than what we expected just a month ago. Some of that's in demand. I think also for the nodes, we didn't lose any sockets over the last 4 months that changed our outlook for the December quarter or the March quarter. So it's more volume. And I think we're also being careful in the timing of new marquee phones that are ramping. This quarter, when you gain significant share, depending on the timing of those ramps, can influence our outlook as well. So when I say cautious, I'm thinking about that as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just lastly, as a clarification for Steve. In terms of OpEx trajectory, I think Steve, you mentioned cost synergies. But then I look at your OpEx guidance in the mid-1 50s, that's sort of flat versus last March --  but this math might be wrong her
componenttext: Got it. Just lastly, as a clarification for Steve. In terms of OpEx trajectory, I think Steve, you mentioned cost synergies. But then I look at your OpEx guidance in the mid-1 50s, that's sort of flat versus last March --  but this math might be wrong here. So where should we see the evidence of cost synergies? Where can we see that in your recorded numbers?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you look at the last 4 quarters, revenue has grown about 12%; OpEx has been basically flat. And so there have really been two uses for the OpEx synergies. First is, we have grown revenue and kept OpEx totally flat. And so that's an accomplishm
componenttext: Sure. So if you look at the last 4 quarters, revenue has grown about 12%; OpEx has been basically flat. And so there have really been two uses for the OpEx synergies. First is, we have grown revenue and kept OpEx totally flat. And so that's an accomplishment. The second key two things is we've been reinvested in R&D. So if you look line-by-line in OpEx, you'll see SG&A is down significantly, R&D is up, roughly to a push, right, in terms of total dollars, but a much more productive avenue spending, apologies to my friends in the SG&A world, but we prefer to spend money in the research and product development. And as soon as synergy achievement has allowed us to do that, and that's going to translate into a faster growth rate in the future. Great question.

componenttext: Yes, so in general, of course, we're very excited about the year we're looking forward to in China, really beginning to catch up on our share, our cash there, we're ramping production in this quarter, our third generation solution, our [indiscernible] solution for that market is capable. And so to a line that Bob was saying, a lot of those principles are ramping after the Lunar New Year, it's kind of second half of the March quarter so that's when into we can piece of that but there's no question that the rate is coming and our shares are going to be increasing there throughout the year. we're also expecting pretty good year in China generally receiving subsidies being increased from the carriers. And also, the requirements for received CA coming in throughout the year, which is going to drive a lot of unique solutions that I think we're very well-positioned to provide.

componenttextpreview: James Klein. We are seeing some rebound in the infrastructure market in China. I think overall, we're up about 18% quarter-over-quarter in that part of the market, and we talked about that for the last 3 or 4 quarters. And we're also seeing positive book-
componenttext: James Klein. We are seeing some rebound in the infrastructure market in China. I think overall, we're up about 18% quarter-over-quarter in that part of the market, and we talked about that for the last 3 or 4 quarters. And we're also seeing positive book-to-bill in this first time we've seen positive book-to-bill in that part of the market as well. So it looks like there's some recovery in the infrastructure side beginning to happen.

componenttext: And then turning -- Steve, on gross margins, can you talk a little bit about puts and takes for gross margins? What's driving the improvement in the March quarter and going forward? Is it utilization in March or mix? And how should we think about margin -- modeling margins on a contribution basis going forward?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think margins have been roughly around 50%. Your model every quarter for 101 different reasons of mix and whatever those are in the quarter. And in the quarter we just completed, we had a couple of yield issues and also, December tends to be a higher qu
componenttext: I think margins have been roughly around 50%. Your model every quarter for 101 different reasons of mix and whatever those are in the quarter. And in the quarter we just completed, we had a couple of yield issues and also, December tends to be a higher quarter for excess and obsolete as our customers in mobile separate the winners from the losers and sometimes, we get to write off a lot of inventory from the losers. And so that, I think, was a oneoff kind of 200 basis point hit of the margins in the December quarter and so it's really coming back to the -- to where we're running naturally, it's around 50%. As you know, our long-term goal is to move margins up to 55%, and we are hard work at both adopting and implementing parts of our manufacturing cost-reduction road map, including some significant changes in filter, wafer sizes and significant activities there. And finally, our completion of our synergies moving to former TriQuint model portfolios test activity into China. So I think there's some good stuff on the longer-term horizon. Next quarter, I think we can kind of come back to our current run rate, which is right around 50%.

componenttext: As I've said in my opening comments, plus we put it in our press release, we feel very good about the design wins that we have in our top 3 customers, marquee phones that are launching this year. Some of those phones begin ramping later in this quarter and we'll see some others as we typically see launches throughout the year. And clearly, they are in the second half. So I feel we have very good visibility into that. Again, I think timing of any marquee phone can vary and when phones ramp at the end of the quarters, that could influence which quarter they fall in, depending on also  what subcons you're shipping into, but harshly feel very about the wins and feel very good about the second half of fiscal 2017 for our mobile products.

And I do believe that at the current price, when you look at the street consensus and the cost of our stock, I think it's an attractive opportunity.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you what, Toshi, I appreciate your question. We'll do our best without giving too much competitive advantage. But I that little more specific but it's broad-based and it's across multiple products that we offered to the markets so I don't
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you what, Toshi, I appreciate your question. We'll do our best without giving too much competitive advantage. But I that little more specific but it's broad-based and it's across multiple products that we offered to the markets so I don't think it's just power amplifiers and switches or just tuners or just diversity receive modules, et cetera. But it's pretty diverse. But I don't know, Eric, if we can comment.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really the key point. I mean, there are some certainly some particular slots that are very high dollar value, but if they're a real strength, and I think of the design wins, and this goes across all 3 of the customers, the things we're looking to r
componenttext: That's really the key point. I mean, there are some certainly some particular slots that are very high dollar value, but if they're a real strength, and I think of the design wins, and this goes across all 3 of the customers, the things we're looking to ramp this year, is it's just the diversity of the applications that we're providing. As you know, with our technologies, we haven't housed, we have access to virtually the entire RF front-end. And so we are able to architect complete solutions and more and more as we go throughout this year and see more adoption of more like a complete solution for Qorvo. And so it includes not just the traditional power amplifiers, switch and even filter markets that antenna tuning is definitely continuing to increase and going down into some mid tier and also, there's a lot of opportunity there. And you mentioned power management as a result of the CET, kick back in and move in to other parts of the portfolio and other basement suppliers. So add all this together with the diversity modules and the RF Fusion modules, and so forth, we have a broad portfolio we're bringing in each of those areas.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up is regarding the Qualcomm TDK joint venture, how do you view that joint venture from a competitive standpoint? I'm guessing the impact of the short-term is minimal, if anything. But I was curious more how you view the landscape on a longe
componenttext: And my follow-up is regarding the Qualcomm TDK joint venture, how do you view that joint venture from a competitive standpoint? I'm guessing the impact of the short-term is minimal, if anything. But I was curious more how you view the landscape on a longer-term basis.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the long-term, We would also echo your comments. And in fact, it opens up opportunities for us. If you look at our Qorvo -- our competitors, there's a couple of interesting things that we all perform across multiple baseband manufacturers and w
componenttext: I think on the long-term, We would also echo your comments. And in fact, it opens up opportunities for us. If you look at our Qorvo -- our competitors, there's a couple of interesting things that we all perform across multiple baseband manufacturers and work with them. And on TDK, as you well know, has been working with several of those manufacturers as well and quite honestly, it's hard for us to think that a media backer, take whatever else you want is going to be able to share with them their front-end designs and their architectures when they know that everything that they tell them is going to basically begin in the Qualcomm, and their RF 360 front-end. So we actually look at this and go this is probably going to open up some opportunities for us. When we made our investments and our filters, clearly, us and our 2 largest competitors buy from TDK and quite honestly, we're just going to in-source more of our own filters. We're bringing up 6-inch. So we think it's going to help our P&L as well. It's going to accelerate the movements that we're making there. But net-net at a high level, it's really changed. That's been their partner since Day 1 to build their modules, build the used filters, et cetera. So if anything, we're looking at and more modest, it will open up more doors for us.

componenttext: Sure, so what I was referring to, Ed, is literally a transition where we're working with our largest customers as well as some of the chipset providers as well to propose literally complete solutions. So we have Qorvo part numbers that span the entire RF front-end and the question just rate and pays of how soon we're able to bring each of the pieces in and get them to fit with the exact configuration for each individual customers we're working for essentially. But going from the mode where someone else is architecting the front-end and giving us specs, and we're responding to those maybe influencing them to work from the very beginning, we say, okay, architect to full front end for us is does x, ,y, z.

componenttext: Yes, mostly 4G base stations. One other thing I would say though is we are seeing a significant amount of interest in LTE A and Pro. And a little bit small cell as well.

componenttext: Let me talk about power and market for GaN and first of all, the best part of that market is really on the defense side of their work and they were obviously actively participating #1 in the market, tremendous amount of product getting released. Really, the cover of broad spectrum of low-frequency, high-power all the way up into product covering. So grea for us in the defense side. and very broad based in the base station, if you look at what some of the forecast throughout the industry, it's projected that GaN will overtake LD as far as total size, somewhere in the next maybe 3 or 4 years. So substantial growth in the GaN. The only loss will continue to decline and that's-driven been the President been talking about in the last several quarters. continuing the increase of bandwidth, the move to massive MIMO, all of those savings are going to drive GaN more and more into the marketplace. And as far as our positioning, wg got products out there released across multiple different bands and we're engaged with the majority of the top OEMs in the space.

componenttext: Yes, the reason inventory didn't perform very well is we have a last minute reduction in the demand for our products. So we built the product, and then we were able to ship it at the end of the quarter. So that was why our returns were at 3.3, which is not anywhere near our expectation. We think you're in north of four. For sure, we think we can achieve that. But I would say the December quarter is somewhat of an anomaly due to the rather abrupt reduction in demand from a particular large customer.

componenttext: Just two, if I could. Could you talk a little bit on the mobile business? You covered China pretty well. How you think things are going in the nonchina emerging markets for your customers? and then back to the cost synergies, it sounds like a little ahead for the first year. Just curious to get to that 1 50 through the end of this fiscal year. What is the legality look like for that? Would that be more back-end loaded or you think we could see some of that comment in the earlier part of next fiscal year?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Eric. So if I understood your question, it was about the nonchina emerging markets and that is an interesting question, I think. It's something that percolates throughout the year. We think roughly 50 million units of 4G smartphones could be
componenttext: Yes, this is Eric. So if I understood your question, it was about the nonchina emerging markets and that is an interesting question, I think. It's something that percolates throughout the year. We think roughly 50 million units of 4G smartphones could be consumed in that kind of emerging market outside of China. The majority of those will be provided by our current customers, of course in a lot of China brands. And one of the things that's interesting is, as a China is moving towards 5-mode or full mode against that, the customers are getting really better and better at including really complex RF in there. And so when they look to these emerging markets, instead of taking your traditional approach of doing that will strip down low cost phone there generally, starting with their full mode phone and adding the bands for those regions to them. And that's one of the things that's driving the antenna tuner demand we talked about in China. Between that and the fact they're also adopting very high quality, global looking fields, if you will, we don't just, for example. all The 3 things that drove antenna atoning into the highest tier, really, that's where our China-based customers are taking their products for all of the 4G markets.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with respect to the timing and the remaining synergies, largely in the second half of the calendar year. While we talk about moving extraculent moving parts, what it really amounts to is beginning new mobile parts in the factor that they're going to b
componenttext: And with respect to the timing and the remaining synergies, largely in the second half of the calendar year. While we talk about moving extraculent moving parts, what it really amounts to is beginning new mobile parts in the factor that they're going to be tested and assembled in. And so it's the significant new product launches that happen in the fall that drive our ability to achieve those synergies.

componenttext: We saw a little bit of a slowdown in our transport business and that was probably one of the biggest offsets. Some of that was just associated with normal decrease in our pricing as we go through volume cuts. Some of that, we think, was a little bit of inventory correction in that part of the business, but I would say that was the most significant offset. And to tell you the truth, we had, in that part of the transport, we had a really strong first half in our cable part of the business. And it's returned sort of what I would call normal levels from the back half. So between those 2 things, that was predominant shift.

componenttext: Okay, got it. And then maybe for Bob, Bob, you mentioned that you were prototyping hexaplexers. Just curious as to when you think you'll be shipping them for production? And also, a follow-up to that, as you go from discrete folders to, what happens to your ASP? The question is, I mean, as you go from 4 to squad, does it just quadruple, or do you see additional increase in your ASP?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to answer the second question first. There's definitely an improvement in the integration and quadplexers far more just 4 filters put together. The circuit design, the ability to actually assemble them and maintain performance and so forth is critical.
componenttext: So to answer the second question first. There's definitely an improvement in the integration and quadplexers far more just 4 filters put together. The circuit design, the ability to actually assemble them and maintain performance and so forth is critical. So there is a different premium over just adding the filters together. And regarding to hexaplexer, that's really going to be determined by the need for 3 CA and higher modes in the phones and the customers we shipped. We think we'll have readiness second half of this year and with the hexaplexers and so we could see production as early as this fall or definitely in calendar '17.

componenttext: Long term, we have a goal to get to 55%. I think it's a goal founded on some significant cost reduction opportunities. And you're right, with IDP coming back, that's accretive to our overall margins, so we'll be very helpful. For the core coming, I think we'll be at 50% and there's a lot of small puts and takes. But again, I see a good opportunity for the company to get to 55% and growth in IDP is surely going to help.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Matt. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from manag
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Matt. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as the risk factors associated with our business in our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC because these risk factors may affect our operations and financial results.
In today's release and on today's call, we provide both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results. We provide this supplemental information to enable investors to perform additional comparisons of operating results and to analyze financial performance without the impact of certain noncash expenses or other items that may obscure trends in our underlying performance.
During our call, our comments and comparisons to income statement items will be based primarily on non-GAAP results. For a complete reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures, please refer to our earnings release issued earlier today, available on our website, qorvo.com, under Investors. [Operator Instructions]
Sitting with me today are Bob Bruggeworth, President and CEO; Steve Buhaly, Chief Financial Officer; Eric Creviston, President of Qorvo's Mobile Products Group; and James Klein, President of Qorvo's Infrastructure and Defense Products Group. I'm also joined by other members of Qorvo's management team.
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call.Revenue in the December quarter was approximately $620 million, consistent with our preannouncement issued January 7. Gross margin and operating margin held i
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call.
Revenue in the December quarter was approximately $620 million, consistent with our preannouncement issued January 7. Gross margin and operating margin held in at 47.9% and 25.3%, respectively. Operating expenses were down sequentially, reflecting less variable compensation expense and seasonally lower spending. Qorvo generated approximately $156.5 million in free cash flow and repurchased $250 million of stock to enhance shareholder value.
In infrastructure and defense, revenue increased sequentially, with improved performance in Wireless Infrastructure. We expect this business to recover further in the near term, reinforcing our top line growth opportunities in calendar 2016.
Our IDP team continues to sharpen its focus on the highest growth segments in its diversified business portfolio. This focus drives alignment with the growth markets of the Internet of Things, connected home, connected car and the high-growth segments within aerospace and defense. By leveraging Qorvo's comprehensive product and technology portfolio, we are providing customers highly differentiated solutions, especially exciting in the growth rate of GaN solutions and in many of IDP's key market segments, driving a compound annual growth rate of approximately 25% for the next few years.
We expect growth rates in 2016 to be well above IDP's underlying markets and significantly above the legacy growth rates of our premerger multi-market organizations.
In mobile, the increase in global demand for broadband data and always-on connectivity continues to trigger a dramatic increase in the requirements for mobile networks and connected devices. For smartphone manufacturers and network operators, it's become increasingly difficult to capitalize on this demand while also solving new challenges related to frequency crowding, as carriers' signals are aggregated, distinct bands and protocols are operated in narrowly adjacent frequency bands and popular new consumer applications increase the congestion on our networks.
For all these reasons, it's increasingly clear that the most effective solutions available to network operators and device manufacturers are better-performing, more highly integrated RF solutions. In fact, if you were to examine the product designs in development for tomorrow's networks and devices, you'd identify increasing requirement for world-class filters, switches, tuners and amplifiers, all tightly packaged in system-level implementations. This is tilting the competitive playing field in Qorvo's favor. Said another way, the RF suppliers with today's best-performing, most tightly integrated solutions are at the forefront of the most challenging and most lucrative customer designs this year, next year and extending well into 2018.
As customers increasingly require more tightly integrated, high-performance system-level solutions, this is favoring Qorvo's comprehensive portfolio of premium products. In fact, this is why we became Qorvo.
Now 1 year into the creation of Qorvo, the roughly 7,000 members of the Qorvo team have much to be proud of. Looking at our first full year, compared to calendar 2014, revenue grew 12%, gross margin expanded more than 400 basis points and operating income increased more than 40%. In fact, the non-GAAP earnings we reported over the last 4 quarters equates to a little over $4.60 per share based on our Q3 share count of approximately 144 million shares.
On the design front, Qorvo is growing our dollar content in the most highly anticipated marquee smartphones launching this year at our 3 largest mobile customers.
It's worth pointing out that in December, we released the industry's first 6-inch temp comp SAW wafers in our Florida fab, qualified 6-inch SAW wafers in our Greensboro fab and demonstrated our first 8-inch BAW wafers in our Texas fab.
We can't overstate how important these achievements are. We see our 6-inch SAW capacity contributing to growth and profitability in the current year, and we see our 8-inch BAW capacity doing the same in 2017.
We commenced shipments of our recently launched BAW-based quadplexers for FDD bands 1 and 3, an industry first, and we demonstrated BAW-based hexaplexer prototypes. We've also been selected to support a number of key cellular platforms with our next-generation envelope tracking PMO. We have commenced production shipments in support of a large global smartphone OEM and has landed a number of large scale wins layering on later this year. We've also recently expanded our shipments of the antenna control solutions into the China smartphone market. Previously, Qorvo's antenna tuners and impedance tuners had been highly concentrated within a small number of high-volume marquee devices. So we're thrilled to be increasing our addressable market in China as these customers add RF functionality to support their expanding presence in the worldwide market.
In IDP, December was an exceptionally strong design win quarter. Here are some of the highlights. We captured multiple key design wins for macro and small cell base station applications. We believe network capacity constraints will accelerate the adoption of small cell base stations and massive MIMO active antennas.
Massive MIMO active antenna systems are driving a 10x increase in RF content in next-generation base stations. We continue to work on capturing new design wins as the market shifts from 4G LTE to LTE-A, LTE Pro and, eventually, 5G.
At this year's Consumer Electronics Show, we supplied a suite of critical microwave components for a 5G massive MIMO demonstration performed by a leading base station OEM. The demo featured Qorvo phase shifters, power amplifiers and switches.
We also expanded our presence in the connected home with key design wins in gateways and access points, highlighted by our design wins and flagship products at both NETGEAR and Linksys.
We continue to believe that the rapidly increasing number of connected devices represented by the Internet of Things will be IDP's largest growth engine. In defense, we are a market leader in GaN, and we continue to experience strong growth with our GaN-based products.
For example, we secured a multi-year win on a next-generation electronic warfare system using our patented Spatium solid-state RF power technology with GaN MMICs with hundreds of system installations anticipated over the life of the contract. On a synergy front, we continue to be on target to achieve our goals, the largest of which include the increase in sourcing of module assembly and increase in sourcing of SAW filters. So for Qorvo, across all our businesses, we believe industry fundamentals remain strong.
We are leveraging our comprehensive product portfolio of world-class RF solutions, rapidly introducing new products and technologies, expanding into new serviceable markets and enjoying very favorable design win activity. We are growing our dollar content in our 3 largest mobile customers, in the most highly anticipated marquee smartphones being released this year. And we anticipate strong growth in IDP.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Steve for a more detailed look at our financials.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. In the December quarter, Qorvo's revenue decreased 12% sequentially to $620 million. Mobile Products revenue declined 15% to $489 million due to lower customer demand for existing business we'd already won. In IDP, revenue grew slightly to $1
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. In the December quarter, Qorvo's revenue decreased 12% sequentially to $620 million. Mobile Products revenue declined 15% to $489 million due to lower customer demand for existing business we'd already won. In IDP, revenue grew slightly to $130 million. Qorvo had two 10% customers, the larger at approximately 42% of revenue, representing the aggregated demand of multiple subcontractors for this end customer.
Our second 10% customer during the quarter was Huawei. Gross margin was 47.9%, down sequentially from 49.7%. The sequential decline reflects lower yields in inventory adjustments.
Operating expenses were approximately $140 million for the December quarter, down $17 million sequentially. The decline was driven by reduced accruals for bonus expense and seasonally lower spending.
Operating income was $156.9 million or just over 25% of revenue. Net income for the December quarter was $148 million or $1.03 per diluted share. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Total cash and investments are over $1 billion, and cash flow from operations totaled $218 million. CapEx was $62 million, primarily to address growth in demand for our premium filters. Finally, the company repurchased approximately 4.6 million shares at a total cost of $250 million and has $750 million remaining in its share repurchase program.
We're proud of Qorvo's first full year performance and excited about the opportunities in the coming year. We're introducing an expanded set of new products, combining switches and filters, and leveraging our broad set of competencies, including BAW filter and gallium nitrite process technologies. All of this is creating exciting new growth opportunities for Qorvo.
With the first full year of Qorvo now in the books, I'm pleased to report the company exceeded its targets for achievement of an exit run rate of $75 million in synergies and is on track for the previously committed $150 million of run rate reduction by the end of calendar 2016. The largest remaining task is migration of all mobile segment parts to the company's China-based assembly and test facilities.
Now let's turn to our business outlook. Qorvo currently believes demand environment in its end markets supports the following non-GAAP expectations for the quarter ending April 2: quarterly revenue of approximately $600 million; gross margin of about 50%; net interest expense of about $15 million; tax rate at approximately 3%; and diluted earnings per share of $0.90 to $0.95 based on approximately 142 million shares. Our March revenue expectations are slightly below our preannouncement, reflecting an overall conservative posture given the cautious environment as well as the timing of new product ramps.
We think calendar 2016 will be a strong year for Qorvo, during which we'll continue to make progress on our target operating model while building a robust and defensible technology moat. Actual quarterly results may differ from these expectations and as such -- and such differences may be material. We currently expect to report March quarter results on May 4.
Now on a personal note, I'm turning 60 at the end of this year, and I've always had it as a personal goal to retire by that point. By December also, fortuitously, marks the end of our second year as Qorvo, and I'm proud to say we're on track to achieve the goals we've set for our first 2-year period. It's been a pleasure being part of Qorvo and helping to shape its course. The company's on a fantastic trajectory, and I'm really looking forward to helping with the transition to a new CFO and participating in the company's success over the balance of the year before moving on to more personal pursuits.
With that, I'm going to hand the call back to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Before opening the call to questions, I want to take a moment to thank Steve for the invaluable role he's played in creating Qorvo. Steve has been instrumental in shaping our organization. He's now put Qorvo on a very solid financial footin
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Before opening the call to questions, I want to take a moment to thank Steve for the invaluable role he's played in creating Qorvo. Steve has been instrumental in shaping our organization. He's now put Qorvo on a very solid financial footing, and he's assembled an outstanding financial organization. The entire Qorvo team is stronger as a result of his contribution, and we are all very happy for him as he looks to spend more time with his family and friends. Until then, he'll play a major role in the selection of his successor and will continue to serve as Qorvo's CFO while the transition to that successor is completed.
And with that, operator, we will now take questions.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] At this time, we'll take the first question from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, when I look at your implied fiscal '16 sales growth, it was modest, and we all know because of the demand weakness around your largest customer. My question is that as we look out to fiscal '17, how fast do you think the total addressable market can
componenttext: Bob, when I look at your implied fiscal '16 sales growth, it was modest, and we all know because of the demand weakness around your largest customer. My question is that as we look out to fiscal '17, how fast do you think the total addressable market can grow? And do you think you can match that growth?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: FY '16, as you pointed out, has been a solid year for us but maybe not as strong as what we have liked. Clearly, we had a few headwinds in the infrastructure market and, as you pointed out, a rather large customer. So moving of off that, we are very confi
componenttext: FY '16, as you pointed out, has been a solid year for us but maybe not as strong as what we have liked. Clearly, we had a few headwinds in the infrastructure market and, as you pointed out, a rather large customer. So moving of off that, we are very confident in the IDP business growing significantly faster than its underlying markets. James and his team have done a great job of realigning their product portfolio to drive above-industry growth there. So I think you're going to see a very nice rebound in growth beginning, actually, in the beginning of our fiscal '17. As you commented on the -- in Eric's business, in the mobile phone business, clearly, we've got a cautious view in the next couple of quarters as we look out in our guidance that we gave for this quarter, along with the beginning of the next fiscal year. With that said, depending on the timing of new program ramps and our confidence in the wins that we already have with our largest 3 customers, I do believe the second half of FY '17 will be very strong and should be above industry growth rates.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I see. And maybe Bob, as a follow-up to that, when you use the word cautious or conservative around demand, is it that your customers are building fewer units than you talked before? Is it comment on your content at those customers? Is that market share? So what is giving you that caution?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Vivek. Let me start with, absolutely, customers are building less phones than what we expected just a month ago even. So some of that is demand. I think what's also important to know is we didn't lose any sockets over the last 4 months that change
componenttext: Thanks, Vivek. Let me start with, absolutely, customers are building less phones than what we expected just a month ago even. So some of that is demand. I think what's also important to know is we didn't lose any sockets over the last 4 months that changed our outlook for the December quarter or the March quarter. So it's more volume. And I think we're also being careful in the timing of new marquee phones that are ramping. This quarter, when you gain significant share, depending on the timing of those ramps, can influence our outlook as well. So when I say cautious, I'm thinking about that as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just lastly, as a clarification for Steve. In terms of OpEx trajectory, I think, Steve, you mentioned cost synergies. But when I look at your OpEx guidance in the mid-150s, that's sort of flat versus last March unless my math is wrong here. So whe
componenttext: Got it. Just lastly, as a clarification for Steve. In terms of OpEx trajectory, I think, Steve, you mentioned cost synergies. But when I look at your OpEx guidance in the mid-150s, that's sort of flat versus last March unless my math is wrong here. So where should we see the evidence of cost synergies? Where can we see that in your reported numbers?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you look at the last 4 quarters, revenue has grown about 12%; OpEx has been basically flat. And so there really have been 2 uses for the OpEx synergies. First is we have grown revenue and kept OpEx totally flat, and so that's an accomplishment
componenttext: Sure. So if you look at the last 4 quarters, revenue has grown about 12%; OpEx has been basically flat. And so there really have been 2 uses for the OpEx synergies. First is we have grown revenue and kept OpEx totally flat, and so that's an accomplishment. The second key thing is we've been reinvested in R&D. So if you look line-by-line in OpEx, you'll see SG&A is down significantly, R&D is up, roughly to a push, right, in terms of total dollars, but a much more productive avenue of spending. Apologies to my friends in the SG&A world, but we prefer to spend money in the research and product development. And synergy achievement has been -- allowed us to do that, and that's going to translate into a faster growth rate in the future. Great question.

componenttext: Yes. So in general, of course, we're very excited about the year we're looking forward to in China, really beginning to catch up on our share, our cash there, we're ramping into production this quarter our third generation solution, our RF Flex solution for that market, it's CA-capable. And sort of aligned to what Bob is saying, a lot of those firms are ramping after the Lunar New Year. It's kind of second half of the March quarter, so that's when we got to see the exact rate and pace of that, but there's no question that the train is coming, and our share is going to be increasing there throughout the year. We're also expecting a pretty good year in China generally. We see the subsidies being increased from the carriers. And also the requirements for received CA coming in throughout the year, which is going to drive a lot of unique solutions, and I think we're very well positioned to provide.

componenttext: Yes. Mike, this is James Klein. We are seeing some rebound in the infrastructure market in China. I think, overall, we're up about 18% quarter-over-quarter in that part of the market. And we've talked about that for the last 3 or 4 quarters. And we're also seeing positive book-to-bill. And it's the first time we've seen a positive book-to-bill in that part of the market as well. So it looks like there's some recovery in the infrastructure side beginning to happen.

And how should we be thinking about margin -- modeling margins on a contribution basis going forward?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think margins have been roughly around 50%. Your mileage varies every quarter for 101 different reasons of mix and whatever goes on in the corner. In the quarter we just completed, we had a couple of yield issues and also, December tends to be a higher
componenttext: I think margins have been roughly around 50%. Your mileage varies every quarter for 101 different reasons of mix and whatever goes on in the corner. In the quarter we just completed, we had a couple of yield issues and also, December tends to be a higher quarter for excess and obsolete as our customers in mobile separate the winners from the losers, and sometimes, we get to write off a little inventory from the losers. And so that, I think, was a one-off kind of a 200 basis point hit to margins in the December quarter, and so it's really coming back to the -- to where we're running naturally, it's around 50%. As you know, our long-term goal is to move margins up to 55%, and we are hard at work at both adopting and implementing parts of our manufacturing cost-reduction road map, including some significant changes in filter, wafer sizes and significant activities there. And finally, our completion of our synergies, moving the former TriQuint mobile portfolio assembly and test activity into China. So I think there's some good stuff on the longer-term horizon. Next quarter, I think we kind of come back to our current run rate, which is right around 50%.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: At this time, we'll take a question from Harsh Kumar with Stephens.

componenttext: I wanted a little bit of clarification. I think you guys touched upon this earlier. Marquee handsets, you see strong demand in the second half, Bob. I was curious if these designs have been won? And also, what kind of visibility do you have for that September, December quarter ramp?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Harsh. As I said in my opening comments, plus we put it in our press release, we feel very good about the design wins that we have in our top 3 customers, marquee phones that are launching this year. Some of those phones begin ramping later in thi
componenttext: Thanks, Harsh. As I said in my opening comments, plus we put it in our press release, we feel very good about the design wins that we have in our top 3 customers, marquee phones that are launching this year. Some of those phones begin ramping later in this quarter, and we'll see some others as you typically see launches throughout the year. And clearly, they are in the second half. So I feel we have very good visibility into that. Again, I think timing of any marquee phone can vary. And when phones ramp at the end of the quarters, they can influence which quarter they fall in, depending on also what sub cons you're shipping into. But Harsh, we feel very good about the wins and feel very good about the second half of fiscal 2017 for our mobile products.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, maybe going to Steve. Steve, you did a $250 million buyback. Was that basically on plan with what you were thinking going into the quarter? Or did you get more aggressive because of where you saw the stock at? And also the $750 mi
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, maybe going to Steve. Steve, you did a $250 million buyback. Was that basically on plan with what you were thinking going into the quarter? Or did you get more aggressive because of where you saw the stock at? And also the $750 million that you were talking about that you have left, Steve, is there a time fuse on it? Does it have to be done in a certain way? Would you just take us over those criteria?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd be delighted to. What I'd say, the December quarter pretty much worked out as planned. And we do have some interest in some dollar costing concept, but we're also opportunistic. So December was this planned, the formal buyback program has 9 more month
componenttext: I'd be delighted to. What I'd say, the December quarter pretty much worked out as planned. And we do have some interest in some dollar costing concept, but we're also opportunistic. So December was this planned, the formal buyback program has 9 more months left to go. Now you and I both know, that's a stroke of a pen with the Board of Directors, but that's the current plan on record. And I do believe that at the current price, when you look at the Street consensus and the cost of our stock, I think it's an attractive opportunity.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I have one short one and then a follow-up. The first one is regarding some of the design wins that you've talked about at your 3 largest mobile customers. Can you maybe provide some granularity as to where you've gained the content and by how much?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll tell you what, Toshi, I appreciate your question. We'll do our best without giving away too much competitive advantage. But -- and I'll let Eric get a little more specific, but it's broad-based. It's across multiple products that we offer to th
componenttext: Well, I'll tell you what, Toshi, I appreciate your question. We'll do our best without giving away too much competitive advantage. But -- and I'll let Eric get a little more specific, but it's broad-based. It's across multiple products that we offer to the markets. So don't think of it as just power amplifiers or just switches or just tuners or just diversity receive modules, et cetera. But it's pretty diverse. But I don't know, Eric, if we can comment.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Yes. I mean, that's really the key point. I mean, there are some -- certainly some particular slots that are very high dollar value. But the real strength, I think, in the design wins, and this goes across all 3 of the customers, the things we're lo
componenttext: Good. Yes. I mean, that's really the key point. I mean, there are some -- certainly some particular slots that are very high dollar value. But the real strength, I think, in the design wins, and this goes across all 3 of the customers, the things we're looking to ramp this year, is just the diversity of the applications that we're providing. As you know, with our technologies we have in-house, we have access to virtually the entire RF front-end. And so we're able to architect complete solutions and more and more -- as we go throughout this year, you're going to see more adoption of more like a complete solution for Qorvo. So -- and it includes, as Bob said, not just the kind of traditional power amplifier and switch and even filter markets, but antenna tuning is definitely continuing to increase and going down into the mid-tier, and also there's a lot of opportunity there. And we mentioned ET power management as well. We're starting to see ET kick back in and move into other parts of the portfolio and other base management [ph] suppliers. So add all this together with the diversity modules and the RF Fusion modules and Flex and so forth, we just have a broad portfolio, we're winning in each of those areas.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And my follow-up is regarding the Qualcomm-TDK joint venture, how do you view that joint venture from a competitive standpoint? I'm guessing the impact in the short term is minimal, if anything. But I was curious more how you view the landsca
componenttext: Okay, great. And my follow-up is regarding the Qualcomm-TDK joint venture, how do you view that joint venture from a competitive standpoint? I'm guessing the impact in the short term is minimal, if anything. But I was curious more how you view the landscape on a longer-term basis.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Toshi. I think on the long term, we would also echo your comments. And in fact, it opens up opportunities for us. If you look at our -- Qorvo  along with our competitors, there's a couple of interesting things that we all perform across multiple b
componenttext: Thanks, Toshi. I think on the long term, we would also echo your comments. And in fact, it opens up opportunities for us. If you look at our -- Qorvo  along with our competitors, there's a couple of interesting things that we all perform across multiple baseband manufacturers and work with them. And TDK, as you well know, has been working with several of those manufacturers as well, and quite honestly, it's hard for us to think that MediaTek or pick whoever else you want is going to be able to share with them their front-end designs and their architectures when they know everything that they tell them is going to basically be given to Qualcomm, in their RF360 front-end. So we actually look at this and go this is probably going to open up some opportunities for us. We made our investments in our filters. Clearly, us and our 2 largest competitors buy from TDK. And quite honestly, we're just going to in-source more of our own filters. We're bringing up 6-inch. So we think it's going to help our P&L as well. It's going to accelerate the movements that we're making there. But net-net at a high level, nothing's really changed. That's been their partner since Day 1 to build their modules, build the fuse, filters, et cetera. So if anything, we're looking at it, and go, wow, this could open up some other doors for us.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Eric, you just said there were more adoption of complete solutions. What does that mean? I mean, does that mean more individual components at your largest customers? Or are the second and third tier OEMs moving more to more integrated parts like pads or Flex or Fusion away from the streets? And then James, you're seeing a rebound in infrastructure. Is that predominantly in China? Or is it more widespread than that? And is it exclusively 4G? Or are you seeing a wider rebound?

componenttext: Eric, go ahead first.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Yes. So what I was referring to, Ed, is literally a transition where we're working with our largest customers as well as some of the chipset providers as well to propose literally complete solutions. So we have Qorvo part numbers that span the entir
componenttext: Sure, Yes. So what I was referring to, Ed, is literally a transition where we're working with our largest customers as well as some of the chipset providers as well to propose literally complete solutions. So we have Qorvo part numbers that span the entire RF front-end, and it's a question of just rate and pace of how soon we're able to bring each of the pieces in and get them to fit with the exact configuration that each individual customer is looking for essentially. But going from an old where someone else is architecting their front-end and giving us specs, and we're responding to those, maybe influencing them to where from the very beginning, they say, "Okay, architect the full front-end for us that does X, Y and Z.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. In the base station recovery, I would say it's broad-based across the OEMs. Some a little more than others. It's sometimes difficult for us to know exactly where our component's going, to what market, but as we look at what our customers are saying, it would appear that, that recovery is based somewhat in China. And then I didn't hear the second part of your question.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it mostly 4G base stations?
componenttext: Is it mostly 4G base stations?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, mostly 4G base stations. One other thing I would say though is we are seeing just a significant amount of interest in LTE-A and Pro. We're seeing our multi MIMO or massive MIMO system start to get demonstrations happening. So there's a lot of other t
componenttext: Yes, mostly 4G base stations. One other thing I would say though is we are seeing just a significant amount of interest in LTE-A and Pro. We're seeing our multi MIMO or massive MIMO system start to get demonstrations happening. So there's a lot of other things that also show that, that market in general is starting to gather some strength. And a little bit in small cell as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, Eric, a follow-up for you, if I could. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that envelope tracking looks like it might be ramping. Can you remind us was that material? Has ET been material to your revenue line in the last year or so? And
componenttext: Great. And then, Eric, a follow-up for you, if I could. You mentioned in the prepared remarks that envelope tracking looks like it might be ramping. Can you remind us was that material? Has ET been material to your revenue line in the last year or so? And then it sounds like you're ramping in more than 1 major OEM with these big flagship product launches. I'm just trying to get a scale of what this is. And I know you don't like talking about your SKUs, but just give us an idea what the revenue opportunity would be, in a TAM kind of sense, would be for envelope tracking. And I have a follow-up on tuning, if I could.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you know, we have ramped ET pretty successfully into one of the leading OEMs a couple of years ago. Now I don't remember the exact timing, but for the past several quarters, those phones had ramped down, and it's not been meaningful at all. So
componenttext: Yes. So as you know, we have ramped ET pretty successfully into one of the leading OEMs a couple of years ago. Now I don't remember the exact timing, but for the past several quarters, those phones had ramped down, and it's not been meaningful at all. So now it's being reinvigorated. We've got a new version coming out, and we're ramping with one of our leading customers currently as we speak with that technology. And it will be profiting throughout their portfolio and potentially moving to other OEMs throughout the year.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just in terms of IDP, in terms of new products, particularly around gallium nitride, can you talk a little bit about how you see the power amplifier market developing there, how much do you think you'll play in that, and GaN versus L
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just in terms of IDP, in terms of new products, particularly around gallium nitride, can you talk a little bit about how you see the power amplifier market developing there, how much do you think you'll play in that, and GaN versus LDMOS replacement planning?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me talk broadly about the power market for GaN. First of all, the best part of that market growth is really on the defense side, and they were obviously actively participating, #1 in the market, tremendous amount of products getting released, really,
componenttext: Let me talk broadly about the power market for GaN. First of all, the best part of that market growth is really on the defense side, and they were obviously actively participating, #1 in the market, tremendous amount of products getting released, really, to cover a broad spectrum of low-frequency, high-power, all the way up into products that are covering cavemen. So great coverage for us in the defense side. Great growth for us in the defense side and very broad-based. In the base station, if you look at what -- some of the forecast throughout the industry, it's projected that GaN will overtake LDMOS as far as total size somewhere in the next maybe 3 or 4 years. So substantial growth in GaN. The LDMOS will continue to decline, and that's driven by the trends that we've been talking about for the last several quarters, continuing to increase the bandwidth, the move to massive MIMO, all of those sort of things are going to drive GaN more and more into this marketplace. And as far as our positioning, we've got products out there released across multiple different bands, and we're engaged with the majority of the top OEMs in the space.
