componenttext: Mike, I also point out to be kind of rushed on last quarter, we felt that the antenna tuners and a lot of those solutions because of the metal cases starting to proliferate in our Chinese customers designs. That's great opportunity for growth for us, not just the power amplifiers, but also high performance bar filters as well as some of our antenna tuners.

componenttext: Question, Bob, for you. As you look in the back of the year, you given the June guide, Steve has kind of talk about the EPS of the year. As you look in the back half of the calendar year, how do you see the market? And I've got a follow up.

componenttext: Yes. As far as the market goes, we're modeling pretty much flat growth. So we still expect the RF for the mobile business 10% to 15%. We've repositioned business tied to get into double-digit growth rate, so coming back to the infrastructure, we are expecting a pretty solid year as we go forward.

componenttext: I just want to add one of the interesting things in our business is a migration from IDP business to kind of high single-digit growth rate to mid-teens growth rate comparable that we see in the mobile space. And the acquisition of GreenPeak is one more step in that direction.

componenttext: And then. Hey, Steve, I think you touched on it very briefly. I think you're supposed to have a major event, but your cost reduction strategy whether you move to China. I was wondering if you could give us small update to that, as it relates to what's going on there?

componenttext: Sure. Happy to. Most of the action was in the second part of the calendar year, as we can't really move parts in our our customers acquire us to start new parts in the location of manufacturer. And so that means we're intersecting with major product launches as typically happen in the back half of the calendar year. So that's where we will start to see the flow of savings at the level we expect.

componenttext: We have good growth in our wireless infrastructure and base station business and also in connectivity. As far as the base station side, it was really broad-based across the regions and across all of our top-tier customers in the space.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay, great. And Eric, very strong growth in China looking into the June quarter. I was wondering you can give us any sense obviously you're ramping Gen 3 of RF FLEX but your premium filters. Can you give us some sense, is it fairly well bal
componenttext: Right, right. Okay, great. And Eric, very strong growth in China looking into the June quarter. I was wondering you can give us any sense obviously you're ramping Gen 3 of RF FLEX but your premium filters. Can you give us some sense, is it fairly well balanced between RF Flex and filters? Or is one of those businesses much larger than the other? And then sort of follow-on question to that is, last year you guys saw massive June quarter in China and ended up inventory stimulation effect at September, December. As you look forward right now, do you think that strength in China sort of continues in the back of the year? Or is it hard to have visibility that far right out now?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question. With the portfolio that's going in June in China, particularly is very, very diverse. In addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the most of the China suppliers. W
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. With the portfolio that's going in June in China, particularly is very, very diverse. In addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the most of the China suppliers. When we look at Huawei, that's a completely different sort of dynamic. We also see them growing strongly in June. But based on the RF Fusion portfolio, some of the more premium solutions and power management and so forth. So really I think its fair to say our entire product portfolio is involved in one way or others with various tiers and manufacturer out in China. And you have to below Huawei, the other suppliers like Oppo, Vivo and Xiaomi, we have good long-term relationships with these guys and they're looking to expand beyond domestic consumption and export more, which is driving a need for more premium filters and more bands in their phones. And so that just plays right into where we're investing. And regarding your second point, yes, very good point, last year we also had very strong start of June. I think that has caused us to be pretty cautious. We're being as careful as we can to make sure looking at the total demand and watching for customers that might be double ordering or chasing the same slots and so forth. So we're watching it very carefully. I think another big part of last year was the MediaTek's Pahse II generation, where we were frankly, behind by 1 or 2 quarters. And it was hard to catch up once we got there. So this transition this time of Phase III and looking into phase 5 and Faye 6 at this time, we look very, very well aligned with the MediaTek as well as the end customers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.
componenttext: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the BAW filtered capacity, the Skyworks now has pretty open it talked about having BAW filters in 2017. And of course, we would be extending the TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansi
componenttext: On the BAW filtered capacity, the Skyworks now has pretty open it talked about having BAW filters in 2017. And of course, we would be extending the TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansion and filter capacity in itself?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity is going to take we are moving to 8-inch. The performance keeps improving, ge
componenttext: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity is going to take we are moving to 8-inch. The performance keeps improving, generation over generation. Quite honestly, I'm not sure where they're getting the technology or where they're even having a factory to produce it. We currently do know suppliers out there that are limited in their ability to use BAW filters, coupled with SAW filters you want to transmit or receive. So we're certainly familiar with those things, but we just don't see it. And as far as high performance figures, whether they are BAW or temp comp SAW, continue to expand the growth. They are bigger than Qorvo in temp comp SAW. We are expanding capacity for programs that we already 1. We migrated to 6-inch, we talked in the February call about how we were qualified to first 6-inch process. We're first in the industry to do that. This quarter, in opening comments, I talked about how we're ramping temp comp SAW in Florida. And again, that's for programs we've already won. But we feel pretty good about the capacity we're putting in place in BAW as well as in SAW. So when I talked about SAW filters in Greensboro, that's really in sourced it is that we're buying outside. But over time, that will be a margin improvement as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. And 1 for Eric, any, when you talk about major components like get aggregation or receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those option comes? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving the co
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. And 1 for Eric, any, when you talk about major components like get aggregation or receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those option comes? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving the content story? And how much of that currently able to let go?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question. I would say generally, we are still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to see which half let's say, with the 4G phones overall this year have you will see and eventually I'm confident you will all have
componenttext: Yes. It's a good question. I would say generally, we are still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to see which half let's say, with the 4G phones overall this year have you will see and eventually I'm confident you will all have it over next 3 to 5 years. In China alone as well, we think somewhere like quarter to a third of even Chinese 4G phones will have carrier aggregation in the downlink this year. So I think overall, we're still in fairly early innings. I think we talked about this at Analyst Day, compounding effect of those with the reduced number of SKUs in the handsets manufacturers pipeline that drives the complexity dramatically. And that overall trend as well, we definitely see our #2 or #3 customer in particular driving towards more of a global SKU like our largest customer does. And that's also still is in the early innings of development.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about a reference to that exposure in China, which is like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fusion? Thanks.
componenttext: You talked about a reference to that exposure in China, which is like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fusion? Thanks.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, we look at the value chain, the more baseband the better from our guys perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to -- to make the products more developing in terms of platforms. And then we can
componenttext: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, we look at the value chain, the more baseband the better from our guys perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to -- to make the products more developing in terms of platforms. And then we can make relatively minor adjustments to customize each individual and platform and customer. We would see any of the vertical baseband guys looking to develop completely new RF architecture. And we're already addressing our of architecture, customers nearly won. So it's now only a matter of interfacing to those individual basebands, relatively straightforward thing to do. And we're happy to do it going very, very well with all the internal vertical suppliers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So bit of a neutral, thanks. And then my follow-up is, really nice June quarter guidance $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall through, I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back or are t
componenttext: Okay. So bit of a neutral, thanks. And then my follow-up is, really nice June quarter guidance $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall through, I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back or are there some other factors getting to the EPS guidance? Thanks.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. We do expect variable comp  to come back, that will lead to OpEx and the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see a kind of
componenttext: Yes. Good question. We do expect variable comp  to come back, that will lead to OpEx and the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see a kind of contrast there. I want to make it clear to folks to expect that. Otherwise, we did improve gross margins sequentially, a lot of that was due to yield differences. And then you have a bit more global mix typical in the June quarter. So all that leads to a guide 50% gross margin.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Adam. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially fro
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Adam. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as the risk factors associated with our business in our Annual Report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC because these risk factors may affect our operations and financial results.
In today's release and on today's call, we provide both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results. We provide this supplemental information to enable investors to perform additional comparisons of operating results and to analyze financial performance without the impact of certain noncash expenses or other items that may obscure trends in our underlying performance.
During our call, our comments and comparisons to income statement items will be based primarily on non-GAAP results. For complete reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures, please refer to our earnings release issued earlier today available on our website, qorvo.com, under Investors. [Operator Instructions]
Sitting with me today are Bob Bruggeworth, President and CEO; Steve Buhaly, Chief Financial Officer; Eric Creviston, President of Qorvo's Mobile Products Group; and James Klein, President of Qorvo's Infrastructure and Defense Products Group. I'm also joined by other members of Qorvo's management team. 
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Revenue for the March quarter totaled $607.1 million, exceeding our quarterly guidance, reflecting increased demand for our highly integrated solutions and a
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. Revenue for the March quarter totaled $607.1 million, exceeding our quarterly guidance, reflecting increased demand for our highly integrated solutions and a return to growth in IDP broad target markets. Gross margin was 50%, up 210 basis points sequentially, reflecting crisp execution by the Qorvo team. Operating margin was 26.4%, with operating expenses of approximately $143 million, reflecting reduced variable compensation expense.
On February 17, we announced an accelerated share repurchase program, and during the March quarter, we were able to repurchase 10 million shares of common stock. We expect to repurchase an estimated 500,000 shares in the June quarter as part of the ASR, and we have $250 million that remain authorized for future repurchases. 
In Mobile Products, revenue was $465 million on the strength of content gains and smartphone program ramps. During the quarter, we launched an increasing number of highly integrated, high-performance solutions that leverage the breadth of our industry-leading portfolio of products and technology. We enjoyed strong demand for our highly integrated solutions, led by products incorporating our premium filters. We expect these highly integrated solutions will continue to drive our growth. 
Qorvo's expanding family of RF Fusion standards -- solution stands out as an example. These tightly integrated compact solutions leveraged our BAW and temp comp SAW filters, our low-loss, high-[indiscernible] SOI switches and our high-performance low-noise amplifiers to deliver performance that's unmatched by competitive solution. In the China market, the deployment of carry aggregation and the migration to 4-mode devices is increasing the demand for our RF Flex solutions, our BAW-based quadplexers and a broad variety of our antenna control solutions. 
Looking into calendar 2017, our customers in China are asking us to integrate our premium filters into RF Flex to reduce complexity and enhance smartphone performance as carrier aggregation proliferates and bands and modes are added. Again, this strongly favors our broad product portfolio and integration capability.
In IDP, revenue grew 9% sequentially to approximately $142 million, reflecting a return to growth in IDP's broad target market. We indicated last quarter that IDP had repositioned its diverse portfolio of businesses to accelerate growth, and we've begun to see the benefit of that sharpened focus. In automotive, IDP secured a significant design win with a Tier 1 automotive supplier, meaningfully expanding our opportunity in automotive infotainment systems at several European car manufacturers.
Elsewhere in connectivity, IDP leveraged the superior performance of our integrated solutions in efficiency, thermal dissipation, range and a number of other key metrics to secure the lead position on Quantenna's QSR10G Wi-Fi solution. This solution enables the industry's first 10G Wave 3 solution through a True 8x8 MIMO configuration for 5 gigahertz networks and a 4x4 MIMO configuration for 2.4 gigahertz networks. 
In Wireless Infrastructure, revenue grew by more than 25% sequentially, and we returned to more historic levels in our base station business.
And in GaN, we enjoyed increasing demand for Qorvo's high-frequency, high-power solutions across both infrastructure deployments and advanced defense applications. 
Across all our market, it's increasingly clear that Qorvo's industry-leading portfolio of RF products and technology represents a significant competitive advantage. Qorvo is offering our customers a combination of performance and integration that's not been available previously, putting us in a favorable position to gain content and outpace our market. Equally important is our unique ability to match the optimum technology or combination of technologies to each customer's application without bias towards any one technology or architecture.
Only Qorvo delivers a comprehensive product portfolio of filters, switches, amplifiers, LNAs and tuners with the scale, integration capabilities and system-level expertise to supply an expanding variety of highly integrated solutions. This is leading to deeper relationships with our customers, channel partners and carriers as they see greater economic value in maximizing spectral efficiency. To monetize their respective investments, they're seeking increasingly precise, highly integrated solutions optimized to solve specific challenges related to the delivery of broadband data. Qorvo is unique in its ability to address that need. 
In both Mobile and IDP, Qorvo is leveraging our comprehensive product and technology portfolio to participate in the development of 5G standards to expand our growth opportunity. We are engaged in 5G field trials with infrastructure customers, and we are assisting in the development of key aspects of 5G next-generation wireless communication standards as a member of 3GPP.
In 2016, 3GPP is set to make significant progress in defining 5G use cases. 5G will enable speeds comparable to fixed broadband with ultralow latency and the capacity for massive scale networks, creating exciting opportunities in new markets like wireless residential broadband, autonomous driving, robotics, virtual reality, urban sensor networks and other applications leveraging deployment of the global Internet of Things ecosystem. 
In IDP, we're introducing highly differentiated products that enable customers in high-growth markets to introduce products at record speed and with higher levels of functionality. As an example, in automotive, our highly integrated solutions maximize data throughput while solving the complex challenges related to spectrum congestion. The compound annual growth rate in automotive connectivity is forecasted to be 45% through the year 2020. And Qorvo's broad portfolio of RF solutions position us favorably for success.
Across all our markets, it's our goal to deliver breakthrough RF solutions that accelerate the delivery of broadband data and create value for our customers and our customers' customers. We intend to leverage our broad scale, industry-leading product and technology portfolio and strong organizational discipline to achieve operational excellence, capture value and deliver superior financial results. 
We prioritize our uses of cash by investing in our business to drive growth, returning capital to shareholders through share repurchases and exploring opportunities for M&A to supplement growth in IDP. Since our earnings conference call last quarter, we repurchased more than 10 million shares of common stock. We made an acquisition to expand into the Internet of Things. We commenced production of 6-inch temp comp SAW in Florida and 6-inch SAW in Greensboro to support a marquee smartphone this calendar year. And we're in the final days of qualifying our 8-inch BAW process in Texas. Our BAW-based hexaplexer prototypes are demonstrating excellent performance, and we began to sample a highly integrated RF Fusion that incorporates our hexaplexers. We see strong growth and increasing customer pull for these types of solutions in the coming years. 
We recently acquired Clean Room space near our Richardson campus to support customer demand for BAW filters, whether they be in discrete implementations, quadplexers, pentaplexers, hexaplexers, diversity receive modules or other highly integrated RF solution. The facility is already fully operational, and it's our goal to incrementally convert the facility to BAW in the back half of next calendar year to support customer BAW demand. As the industry's leading supplier of SAW, temp comp SAW and BAW devices, we are adding capacity to keep pace with the increase in customer demand for our high-, mid- and low-band products. In fact, Qorvo will soon be in production with low-band PADs, mid-band PADs and high-band PADs, all in premium-tier marquee LTE smartphones.
Before handing off the call to Steve, I want to say a quick word about our acquisition of GreenPeak Technologies, which just recently closed. GreenPeak is a recognized leader in ultra-low power, short-range RF solutions with an expanding business and customers all over the globe, a great number of whom are already purchasing high-power solutions from Qorvo. GreenPeak will become a part of IDP and will be run by Cees Links, their founder and CEO. Cees Links is a recognized industry leader, who was instrumental in the development and adoption of Wi-Fi technology. We expect GreenPeak's ultra-low-power RF solutions and SoCs for the connected home and Internet of Things to nicely complement IDP's industry-leading portfolio of high-power solutions.
We have not included any revenue from GreenPeak Technologies in our June guidance. In the September quarter, we'll have a full quarter of GreenPeak revenue, and we'll begin to include it in our guidance then. 
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Steve for a more detailed look at our financials.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's revenue for the March quarter was $607 million, much better than typical seasonality relative to the December quarter. Mobile Products revenue declined 5% to $465 million, while IDP showed continued strength as revenue grew 9% to $142
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's revenue for the March quarter was $607 million, much better than typical seasonality relative to the December quarter. Mobile Products revenue declined 5% to $465 million, while IDP showed continued strength as revenue grew 9% to $142 million. Content gains in the Samsung Galaxy were the largest driver of the healthy sequential performance in Mobile. Qorvo had 3 10% customers, the largest at approximately 33% of revenue, representing the aggregated demand of multiple subcontractors for this end customer. Our other 10% customers during the quarter were Samsung and Huawei.
Gross margin was 50%, up sequentially from 47.9%, reflecting the absence of a couple of yield issues experienced in the prior quarter. Operating expenses remained relatively low at $143 million, driven by reduced variable compensation expense.
Operating income was $161 million or just over 26% of revenue. Net income for the March quarter was $143 million or $1.04 per diluted share based on 137.5 million shares outstanding. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Total cash and investments were $613 million, and cash flow from operations totaled $160.5 million. Capital expenditures were $84.4 million, primarily to address growth in demand for our premium filters. The company repurchased approximately 10 million shares during the March quarter under our $500 million accelerated share repurchase program. As the actual purchase occurred about halfway through the quarter, the impact on the March quarter share count was about 5 million shares. We expect to repurchase an estimated 500,000 shares this quarter as the ASR program is completed. ASR is part of our previously announced $1 billion share repurchase program approved in November of 2015.
After giving effect to the ASR, approximately $250 million remain authorized under this program for future repurchases. We made good progress last quarter on significant long-term opportunities to improve our growth and profitability. We acquired a highly respected IoT firm, improving our SAM and growth prospects. We continue to improve both the fundamental performance capabilities of our SMR BAW process and the capacity to produce to growing customer demand. Our acquisition of a former Maxim plant just a few miles from our existing operation in Richardson will provide low-cost, Clean Room capacity for the next leg of BAW growth. We saw strong progress on large cost-reduction initiatives, 8-inch BAW wafers, 6-inch TC-SAW wafers and the in-sourcing of mobile assembly and test into our Chinese plants. It's an exciting time in RF and at Qorvo.
Now let's turn to our business outlook. Qorvo currently believes the demand environment in its end markets supports the following non-GAAP expectations for the quarter ending July 2, 2016: quarterly revenue of about $650 million, gross margin of about 50%, net interest expense of approximately $15 million, a tax rate at approximately 10%, and diluted earnings per share of approximately $1.05 based on approximately 133 million shares outstanding. Our June revenue expectations indicate healthy 7% sequential growth, reflecting our strong book of business. Actual quarterly results may differ from these expectations, and as such, differences may be material. We currently expect to report June quarter results on August 2, 2016. 
With that, I'd like to welcome your questions.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up is on the inventory situation. When I look at your balance sheet, I think inventory was up about $80 million on a year-over-year basis, while revenues were down about $25 million. Should we be concerned about your inventory level? O
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up is on the inventory situation. When I look at your balance sheet, I think inventory was up about $80 million on a year-over-year basis, while revenues were down about $25 million. Should we be concerned about your inventory level? Or do your current booking status support significant revenue growth so that we shouldn't be concerned here?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you should be too concerned, but 2 things to think about here. One is we are doing some advanced building in anticipation of growth later this year. And then second, I think our inventory levels are a little heavy, and we can improve our tur
componenttext: I don't think you should be too concerned, but 2 things to think about here. One is we are doing some advanced building in anticipation of growth later this year. And then second, I think our inventory levels are a little heavy, and we can improve our turns performance, and we expect to do so. I don't have a concern about excess and obsolete-type risks. We monitor that closely. We just went through our quarterly review, and I don't have concerns there. But I think that is an area where we can improve, and we'll do so.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Mike Burton from Brean Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Mike Burton from Brean Capital.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up, I guess, on that second question first. Steve, if you could talk us through kind of the puts and takes on gross margin, with revenues heading up in the June quarter, and then your thoughts about it going forward.
componenttext: Just following up, I guess, on that second question first. Steve, if you could talk us through kind of the puts and takes on gross margin, with revenues heading up in the June quarter, and then your thoughts about it going forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So relative to the June quarter, we're back to expectation of 50%. As you might remember, that's pretty much where we've been running the last several quarters. Last quarter, we had a yield issue on a couple of parts that knocked us down to just unde
componenttext: Yes. So relative to the June quarter, we're back to expectation of 50%. As you might remember, that's pretty much where we've been running the last several quarters. Last quarter, we had a yield issue on a couple of parts that knocked us down to just under 48%. In the absence of that, we're kind of back to where we have been at. And relative to the full year, I'll offer a couple of things since you asked. One is we continue to believe our market is growing at a 10% to 15% rate, and we believe we'll grow consistent with that. Second, I think we have, with that growth rate, a good opportunity to see fiscal year '17 earnings per share getting pretty close to $5 a share. If all goes well, we might hit that $5. But I would say by our modeling, I'd say we'll [indiscernible] to the neighborhood. We'll get pretty close to $5. And beyond that, I'm going to -- gross margin and OpEx, that mix will depend on the type of business and opportunities we have as we go through the year. And I'll add I think tax rate should be about 10%, and next quarter, we expect shares to be about 133 million, and we'll see what we do from there on.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if I also -- Eric, it sounds like China's picking up for you guys in Q2. I wonder if you're already starting to see some progress that you were planning on making at MediaTek. And then just also, if you could just clarify, I know you said
componenttext: Great. And then if I also -- Eric, it sounds like China's picking up for you guys in Q2. I wonder if you're already starting to see some progress that you were planning on making at MediaTek. And then just also, if you could just clarify, I know you said growing in Q2, but was China up or down for you guys in Q1 as well?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mike. No question, we're much happy with our position at MediaTek now than we were 6 to 9 months ago. We announced in Barcelona the RF Flex GEN-3 solutions, which are aligned with both MediaTek and Qualcomm, frankly, and seeing a pretty good
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mike. No question, we're much happy with our position at MediaTek now than we were 6 to 9 months ago. We announced in Barcelona the RF Flex GEN-3 solutions, which are aligned with both MediaTek and Qualcomm, frankly, and seeing a pretty good uptake. We saw -- exiting the March quarter, we began to see China really take off. So they were okay in March, but they weren't really the factor that helped offset seasonality as much as Samsung was.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I will also point out, as we touched on last quarter, we kind of let you guys know that we felt that the antenna tuners and a lot of those solutions, because of the metal cases, starting to proliferate in our Chinese customers' designs. That's a gre
componenttext: Mike, I will also point out, as we touched on last quarter, we kind of let you guys know that we felt that the antenna tuners and a lot of those solutions, because of the metal cases, starting to proliferate in our Chinese customers' designs. That's a great opportunity for growth for us. So not just the power amplifiers. It's also our high-performance BAW filters as well as some of our antenna tuners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Harsh Kumar from Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from Harsh Kumar from Stephens.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question, Bob, for you. As you look in the back half of the quarter, you've given the June guide. Steve's kind of talked about the EPS for the year. As you look in the back half of the calendar year, how do you see the market? And then I've got a follow
componenttext: A question, Bob, for you. As you look in the back half of the quarter, you've given the June guide. Steve's kind of talked about the EPS for the year. As you look in the back half of the calendar year, how do you see the market? And then I've got a follow-up.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the market goes, we're modeling pretty much flat handset growth. We're expecting people to continue to migrate up into the performance phones and as well as the marquee phones and driving the dollar content will continue to increase. So we still
componenttext: As far as the market goes, we're modeling pretty much flat handset growth. We're expecting people to continue to migrate up into the performance phones and as well as the marquee phones and driving the dollar content will continue to increase. So we still expect the RF TAM for the Mobile business to grow 10% to 15%. We've repositioned James' business to start to get into double-digit growth rates, so they're coming back to the infrastructure. We are expecting a pretty solid year as we go forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to add. One of the exciting things in our business is the migration of the IDP business from kind of a high single-digit growth rate to a mid-teens growth rate, comparable to what we see in the Mobile space. And this acquisition of GreenPeak i
componenttext: I just want to add. One of the exciting things in our business is the migration of the IDP business from kind of a high single-digit growth rate to a mid-teens growth rate, comparable to what we see in the Mobile space. And this acquisition of GreenPeak is one more step in that direction.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then -- Steve, I think you touched on it just very briefly. I think you were supposed to have a major event with your cost-reduction strategy. When do you move to China? I was wondering if we could get a small update on that as it relates to w
componenttext: Got it. And then -- Steve, I think you touched on it just very briefly. I think you were supposed to have a major event with your cost-reduction strategy. When do you move to China? I was wondering if we could get a small update on that as it relates to what's going on there?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. Most of the action is in the second half of the calendar year as we can't really move parts that are in production. Our customers require us to start new parts in the location of manufacture. And so that means we're intersecting with major
componenttext: Sure, happy to. Most of the action is in the second half of the calendar year as we can't really move parts that are in production. Our customers require us to start new parts in the location of manufacture. And so that means we're intersecting with major product launches that, as typical, happen in the back half of the calendar year. So that's when we'll start to see the flow of savings at the level we expect. So you'll see a little bit of the benefit this calendar year, and you'll see all of the benefit next calendar year. And we are on track for the second $75 million installment of our synergy expectations.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, there was the long list of products groups that are now using BAW, everything from diversity modules, SAW and all-in-ones like Fusion. Does that impact...
componenttext: Eric, there was the long list of products groups that are now using BAW, everything from diversity modules, SAW and all-in-ones like Fusion. Does that impact...

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you speak up a little bit, Ed. It's hard to hear you. I know it's hard to believe, but we've...
componenttext: Can you speak up a little bit, Ed. It's hard to hear you. I know it's hard to believe, but we've...

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I could. Let me speak normal voice now. Check. Can you hear me now? You asked for it, okay.  So Eric, so there's the long list of product groups now using BAW, everything from diversity, I guess, to all-in-ones like Fusion. Did that impact your mix e
componenttext: Yes, I could. Let me speak normal voice now. Check. Can you hear me now? You asked for it, okay.  So Eric, so there's the long list of product groups now using BAW, everything from diversity, I guess, to all-in-ones like Fusion. Did that impact your mix enough in mobile to drive growth at operating margins? And do you expect that to occur or accelerate as they move through the year? And then Steve, you've touched on there the PAD facility in China. Has much or any of TriQuint product lines were there? I guess, it's mostly new Qorvo product lines because you can't move old ones back there.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly. Exactly.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What percentage are you in terms of moving to the PAD facility at this stage? And I have one for James.
componenttext: What percentage are you in terms of moving to the PAD facility at this stage? And I have one for James.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer yours first. I'd say we're under 50% right now and maybe closer to 25%. So it's a relatively modest portion just because of the lead times to equip the factory, start the prototypes, intersect with customer product launches. So that's majority
componenttext: I'll answer yours first. I'd say we're under 50% right now and maybe closer to 25%. So it's a relatively modest portion just because of the lead times to equip the factory, start the prototypes, intersect with customer product launches. So that's majority of it will be second half of the calendar year.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to the first part A, B and C of your question, the BAW product portfolio has filled up very nicely, as you said. And we are shipping, in addition to the diversity receive modules now with BAW in it, several RF Fusion modules with BAW. And as you know,
componenttext: And to the first part A, B and C of your question, the BAW product portfolio has filled up very nicely, as you said. And we are shipping, in addition to the diversity receive modules now with BAW in it, several RF Fusion modules with BAW. And as you know, we released our first quadplexer for the China CA market also BAW-based. And traction in all of those has been very strong in March and continuing on into June and certainly driving a part of our growth. And as we talked about, the gross margins on those are above our average, so that supports the expansion in gross margin. But of course, the growth being driven by that also helps the operating margin, to your point.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, James, most of -- there's a good -- nice uptick in your business this quarter. Was it most all 4G base stations? And was that spread evenly across your customers? Did you see more of a [indiscernible] strength in certain areas?
componenttext: Okay. And then, James, most of -- there's a good -- nice uptick in your business this quarter. Was it most all 4G base stations? And was that spread evenly across your customers? Did you see more of a [indiscernible] strength in certain areas?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have good growth in the wireless infrastructure, our base station business and also in connectivity. As far as the base station side, it was really broad-based across the regions and across all of our top-tier customers in the space.
componenttext: We have good growth in the wireless infrastructure, our base station business and also in connectivity. As far as the base station side, it was really broad-based across the regions and across all of our top-tier customers in the space.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Quinn Bolton from Needham.
componenttext: The next question comes from Quinn Bolton from Needham.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could just comment about inventory levels at your largest customer. It seems like they've obviously seen a lower-than-expected demand. And I'm just wondering, do you think that, that supply chain, I'll hear as you come out of March, l
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could just comment about inventory levels at your largest customer. It seems like they've obviously seen a lower-than-expected demand. And I'm just wondering, do you think that, that supply chain, I'll hear as you come out of March, looking into June, is fairly clean? Or do you think that there's excess component inventory that you may have shipped in previous quarters that still needs to be worked off? And then I've got a follow-up for Eric.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think you're going to like my answer, but I think things are fine. We're in pretty good shape there. So not really much to add. I mean, things look fine to us.
componenttext: Well, I don't think you're going to like my answer, but I think things are fine. We're in pretty good shape there. So not really much to add. I mean, things look fine to us.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a channel that's pretty clean from your perspective, it sounds like?
componenttext: So it's a channel that's pretty clean from your perspective, it sounds like?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you know, and I'm sure you remember, we kind of took the medicine in the December quarter in terms of lowered expectations for that particular customer.
componenttext: And you know, and I'm sure you remember, we kind of took the medicine in the December quarter in terms of lowered expectations for that particular customer.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay, great. And then for Eric, just obviously very strong growth in China here looking into the June quarter. Wondering if you can give us some sense. Obviously, you're ramping GEN-3 of RF Flex, but you also shipped some of the premium filt
componenttext: Right, right. Okay, great. And then for Eric, just obviously very strong growth in China here looking into the June quarter. Wondering if you can give us some sense. Obviously, you're ramping GEN-3 of RF Flex, but you also shipped some of the premium filters. Can you give us some sense, is it fairly well balanced between RF Flex and filters? Or is one of those businesses much larger than the other? And then sort of a follow-on question to that is, last year, you guys saw a massive June quarter in China, and you ended up bleeding to some inventory accumulation that affected September, December. As you look forward right now, do you think that, that strength in China sort of continues in the back half of the year? Or is it hard to have visibility that far out right now?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question. It's -- the -- for the portfolio, it's growing in June in China and, in particular, is very, very diverse; in addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the -- most o
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question. It's -- the -- for the portfolio, it's growing in June in China and, in particular, is very, very diverse; in addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the -- most of the China suppliers. When we look at Huawei, that's a completely different sort of dynamic. We also see them growing strongly in June. But based more on the RF Fusion portfolio, some of them more premium solutions and power management and so forth. So really, I think its fair to say our entire product portfolio is involved in one way or the other with various tiers and manufacturers throughout China. And you have to remember, of course, even the below Huawei, the other suppliers, the other leading suppliers like OPPO, vivo and Xiaomi, we have very good long-term relationships with these guys. And they're looking to expand beyond just domestic consumption and export more, which is driving a need for more premium filters and more bands in their phones. And so that just plays right into where we're investing. And then regarding your second point, yes, a very good point. Last year, we also had a very strong start to June. I think that has caused us to be pretty cautious. We are being just as -- just careful as we can to make sure we're looking at the total demand and watching for customers that might be double ordering or chasing the same slots and so forth. So we're watching that really carefully. I think another big part of last year was the MediaTek Phase 2 generation, where we were, frankly, behind by 1 or 2 quarters. And it was hard to catch up once we got there. And that's -- so this transition this time with Phase 3 and then looking into Phase 5 and Phase 6 at this time, we look very, very well aligned with MediaTek as well as the end customers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.
componenttext: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the BAW filter capacity, with Skyworks now pretty openly talking about having BAW filters in 2017 and then, of course, with them expanding their TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansi
componenttext: On the BAW filter capacity, with Skyworks now pretty openly talking about having BAW filters in 2017 and then, of course, with them expanding their TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansion in filter capacity you've done yourself?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity it's going to take. We're moving to 8 inch. And the performance keeps improvi
componenttext: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity it's going to take. We're moving to 8 inch. And the performance keeps improving generation over generation. Quite honestly, I'm not sure where they're getting the technology or where they're even have a factory to produce it. We currently do know of suppliers out there that are limited in their ability to use BAW filters, coupled with a SAW filter, and you pick it or you want the BAW on transmit or receive. So we're certainly familiar with those things but just don't see it. And as far as temp-comp SAW goes, high performance filters, whether they're BAW or temp-comp SAW, continue to expand and grow. They are bigger than Qorvo in temp-comp SAW. We are expanding capacity for programs that we've already won. Like I said, we migrated to 6 inch. We talked in the February call about how we qualified to 6-inch process. So we're first in the industry to do that. This quarter, in my opening comments, I talked about how we're ramping temp-comp SAW in Florida. And again, that's for programs we've already won. But we feel pretty good about the capacity we're putting in place in BAW as well as in SAW. So when I talked about SAW filters in Greensboro, that's really to in-source filters that we're buying outside, that over time, that will be a margin improvement as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one for Eric. Eric, when you talk about major drivers like carrier aggregation or diversity receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those option curves? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving the
componenttext: And one for Eric. Eric, when you talk about major drivers like carrier aggregation or diversity receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those option curves? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving the content story? And how much of that currently are able up to go?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. I would say generally, we're still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to CA, which half, let's say, of the 4G phones overall this year will have CA. And eventually, I'm confident they'll all have that
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. I would say generally, we're still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to CA, which half, let's say, of the 4G phones overall this year will have CA. And eventually, I'm confident they'll all have that over the next 3 to 5 years. In China alone as well, we think somewhere like 1/4 to 1/3 of even the Chinese 4G phones will have carrier aggregation in the downlink this year. So I think overall, we're still in fairly early innings. Remember, I think we talked about this at Analyst Day. It's a compounding effect of those with the reduced number of SKUs in the handset manufacturers' pipeline that drives the complexity up dramatically. And so that overall trend as well, we definitely see our #2 or #3 customer, in particular, driving towards more of a global SKU like our largest customer does. And that also is still in the early innings of development.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, congrats on outperforming other smartphone suppliers. You talked about a reference to that exposure in China, places like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fu
componenttext: Yes, congrats on outperforming other smartphone suppliers. You talked about a reference to that exposure in China, places like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fusion?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, when you look at the value chain, the more basebands the better from an RF guy's perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to common -- to make the products that we're developing relatively commo
componenttext: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, when you look at the value chain, the more basebands the better from an RF guy's perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to common -- to make the products that we're developing relatively common in terms of platforms. And then we can make relatively minor adjustments to customize for each individual baseband platform or end customer. We don't see any of the vertical baseband guys looking to develop a completely new RF architecture, for example, right? And we're already addressing those architectures that our customers fundamentally want. So now it's only a matter of interfacing to those individual basebands, relatively straightforward thing to do. And we're happy to do -- doing very, very well with all the internal vertical suppliers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so a bit of a neutral. And then my follow-up is -- really nice June quarter guidance of $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall-through. I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back, or are t
componenttext: Okay, so a bit of a neutral. And then my follow-up is -- really nice June quarter guidance of $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall-through. I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back, or are there some other factors getting to the EPS guidance?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. We do expect variable comp to come back. That will lead to OpEx in the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see kind of a c
componenttext: Yes, good question. We do expect variable comp to come back. That will lead to OpEx in the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see kind of a contrast there, and I want to make it clear to folks to expect that. Otherwise, we did improve gross margins sequentially. A lot of that was due to yield differences. And then you have a bit more mobile in the mix typically in the June quarter. So all that leads to a guide of 50% gross margin.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Blayne Curtis from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Blayne Curtis from Barclays.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about your China customers up in June. Maybe you could just talk about trends of your 2 largest customers, what you're embedding into that June guidance. And then, Steve, I just wanted to follow up on the OpEx. You said for GreenPeak in S
componenttext: You talked a lot about your China customers up in June. Maybe you could just talk about trends of your 2 largest customers, what you're embedding into that June guidance. And then, Steve, I just wanted to follow up on the OpEx. You said for GreenPeak in September, what's the visibility to the close there? I think you said within the quarter. And any guidance as to what's the add in the September quarter? Or would you rather just leave it out?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with respect to GreenPeak, it just closed a few days ago, so we'll have some fractional impact in the quarter when we report that -- when report the results of this quarter. But from an earnings perspective, consider it de minimis either way. And
componenttext: Yes. So with respect to GreenPeak, it just closed a few days ago, so we'll have some fractional impact in the quarter when we report that -- when report the results of this quarter. But from an earnings perspective, consider it de minimis either way. And then you're right, I would prefer to talk about GreenPeak financially when we guide the September quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Blayne, as far as our 2 largest customers, I'm not sure you know who they are. I know you clearly know who the largest one is. So I want to be careful. We're kind of splitting hairs maybe on this. But clearly, our largest customer, we're being conserv
componenttext: And Blayne, as far as our 2 largest customers, I'm not sure you know who they are. I know you clearly know who the largest one is. So I want to be careful. We're kind of splitting hairs maybe on this. But clearly, our largest customer, we're being conservative in our guidance. We do believe down to maybe flat, we'll just see. They got some pretty good selling products that we've got nice dollar content in. So -- but down to flat for our largest. Our second largest, depending on which one of those you pick, one's going to be down slightly, and one's going to be up. So I gave you the top 3. How's that?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate it. I guess the 2 largest in the end markets, obviously, it changes.
componenttext: I appreciate it. I guess the 2 largest in the end markets, obviously, it changes.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Tim Arcuri from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Tim Arcuri from Cowen and Company.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question is, can you give us some sense in fiscal 2016 maybe what the percentage of your mobile revenues came from Chinese OEMs?
componenttext: I guess the first question is, can you give us some sense in fiscal 2016 maybe what the percentage of your mobile revenues came from Chinese OEMs?

componenttextpreview: Over the last year, in total, yes, so if you -- are you including Huawei as a Chinese OEM, or you consider that global?
componenttext: Over the last year, in total, yes, so if you -- are you including Huawei as a Chinese OEM, or you consider that global?

componenttextpreview: Include them.
componenttext: Include them.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in -- on the range of mobile business, on a range of 40%, probably including Huawei.
componenttext: Yes, so in -- on the range of mobile business, on a range of 40%, probably including Huawei.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then second question is on the share repo. You bought back 10 million shares in March. I know that some of that is going to spill over into June from kind of how it closed in the P&L. But you said that you're only going to buy back 500,00
componenttext: Okay, great. And then second question is on the share repo. You bought back 10 million shares in March. I know that some of that is going to spill over into June from kind of how it closed in the P&L. But you said that you're only going to buy back 500,000 shares in June, which is down a lot. And that's still not even working through the $250 million that you have left on the repo. So I'm wondering why you're cranking down the repo so much in June. Is that related to the stock price? Or is there something else happening now?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. The ASR that we initiated was initiated mid-quarter of the March quarter. And so we paid Bank of America $500 million. They tendered about 10 million shares to us. And since share count for a quarter is based on the average for
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things. The ASR that we initiated was initiated mid-quarter of the March quarter. And so we paid Bank of America $500 million. They tendered about 10 million shares to us. And since share count for a quarter is based on the average for that quarter, we get about half credit this quarter, half credit next quarter. The next point, the ASR is not finished yet. Our partner Bank of America is completing that program this quarter, and exact share count tender will depend on the average share price that we end up with. So our estimate is we'll pick up another 0.5 million shares or so as that program comes to completion. Once that program is complete, our board will evaluate whether to proceed with a subsequent buyback utilizing the remaining $250 million previously authorized.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job at what you produced in the March quarter. First question, for Steve, on the gross margin, you're guiding flat gross margin but 7% sequential revenue growth. How should we think about your long-term target model of 55%? Has there anything changed
componenttext: Good job at what you produced in the March quarter. First question, for Steve, on the gross margin, you're guiding flat gross margin but 7% sequential revenue growth. How should we think about your long-term target model of 55%? Has there anything changed on that? And then I have a follow-up for Eric.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think the big drivers for us getting from where we're at, which is roughly 50%, to our long-term model of 55% are really those big movers in the gross margin line we referred to earlier. Moving BAW filters from 6-inch wafers to 8-inch wafers, SA
componenttext: Yes, so I think the big drivers for us getting from where we're at, which is roughly 50%, to our long-term model of 55% are really those big movers in the gross margin line we referred to earlier. Moving BAW filters from 6-inch wafers to 8-inch wafers, SAW and TC-SAW from 4 inch to 6 inch, both of those have an effect of taking roughly 1/3 of the cost out of the die for BAW filters and SAW and TC-SAW filters, very significant reductions. We'll be consolidating our gas production and do a single foundry over the next 1.5 years. In-sourcing assembly and test for a part of our mobile business, the part that used to be belonging to TriQuint. And each of these have a significant impact, which is largely going to be felt in FY '18. These will occur throughout the year, but the financial impact will be mostly in FY '18. And then we'd also simply have scale benefits of the kind of growth I referenced to earlier. We have a fair amount of fixed cost, and we will see scale benefits as we continue to grow with the market. And we'll -- we expect it'll be a 10% to 15% rate. So I'm actually -- short term, I think we're going to fluctuate around, depending on the particulars of the quarter. But long term, these are big substantial items that don't involve new laws of physics. This is stuff we can do. We are well underway. And I think we are on track to get to the target model over time.

componenttext: Yes. And even if you look at our WiFi growth, which is -- we haven't talked about that today at all, but we're also seeing very strong growth in our Fusion module for WiFi. componenttext: So yes, again, this is James. The relative size, I think that's too good estimate, but it's broken into those 4 areas in relatively size -- same size. And the growth rates that we've talked about before, probably single digits or so; high single digits in defense. Our connectivity business or WiFi business, we still see growing close to that 20% range. That's what the market is doing. And those are really probably the big, big drivers in the business. I will say that with moving our portfolio around, we've repositioned into really some significant high-growth areas. We've moved about 60% of the business into what we consider above-average growth markets, and those are markets that are growing in the 20% kind of range. The addition of GreenPeak really substantially helps that. GreenPeak's market's targeted to grow about 60% between now and 2020. And so very high growth as we move into the connected home and really start to see IoT take off.

componenttext: Yes. So it's what I was trying to address.
