componenttext: My first question is regarding your revenue performance, both in the March quarter and in the June quarter. You seem to be clearly outperforming the overall industry. You talked to content gains in the Samsung Galaxy. But were there any other things that led to this outperformance?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for your comments, Toshi. And clearly, IDP had strong growth, as we touched on, in the infrastructure business as well as the connectivity business in the March quarter for pretty good performance. Also as you pointed out, we saw good strength from
componenttext: Thanks for your comments, Toshi. And clearly, IDP had strong growth, as we touched on, in the infrastructure business as well as the connectivity business in the March quarter for pretty good performance. Also as you pointed out, we saw good strength from one of our 10% customers. I think it would be good -- as we look at the June guidance, we are expecting both businesses to grow in June, but I will tell you the majority of the growth is going to be coming from the Mobile business. So I'll let Eric talk a little bit about the growth.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Yes, I think in the June quarter we are expecting to be up significantly outside of our largest customer, in particular. And that's driven primarily by just the continued content growth in China. I think we're back on track with the next-gene
componenttext: Thanks, Bob. Yes, I think in the June quarter we are expecting to be up significantly outside of our largest customer, in particular. And that's driven primarily by just the continued content growth in China. I think we're back on track with the next-generation solutions. We've announced RF Flex GEN-3 and is already ramping into high-volume production. That's helping to carry some of the sequential growth.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up is on the inventory situation. When I look at your balance sheet, I think inventory was up about $80 million on a year-over-year basis, while revenues were down about $25 million. Should we be concerned about your inventory level? O
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up is on the inventory situation. When I look at your balance sheet, I think inventory was up about $80 million on a year-over-year basis, while revenues were down about $25 million. Should we be concerned about your inventory level? Or do your current booking status support significant revenue growth so that we shouldn't be concerned here?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think you should be too concerned, but 2 things to think about here. One is we are doing some advanced building in anticipation of growth later this year. And then second, I think our inventory levels are a little heavy, and we can improve our tur
componenttext: I don't think you should be too concerned, but 2 things to think about here. One is we are doing some advanced building in anticipation of growth later this year. And then second, I think our inventory levels are a little heavy, and we can improve our turns performance, and we expect to do so. I don't have a concern about excess and obsolete-type risks. We monitor that closely. We just went through a quarterly review, and I don't have concerns there. But I think that is an area where we can improve, and we'll do so.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Mike Burton from Brean Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Mike Burton from Brean Capital.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up, I guess, on that second question first. Steve, if you could talk us through kind of the puts and takes on gross margin, with revenues heading up in the June quarter, and then your thoughts about it going forward.
componenttext: Just following up, I guess, on that second question first. Steve, if you could talk us through kind of the puts and takes on gross margin, with revenues heading up in the June quarter, and then your thoughts about it going forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So relative to the June quarter, we're back to expectation of 50%. As you might remember, that's pretty much where we've been running the last several quarters. Last quarter, we had a yield issue on a couple of parts that knocked us down to just unde
componenttext: Yes. So relative to the June quarter, we're back to expectation of 50%. As you might remember, that's pretty much where we've been running the last several quarters. Last quarter, we had a yield issue on a couple of parts that knocked us down to just under 48%. In the absence of that, we're kind of back to where we have been at. And relative to the full year, I'll offer a couple of things since you asked. One is we continue to believe our market is growing at a 10% to 15% rate, and we believe we'll grow consistent with that. Second, I think we have with that growth rate a good opportunity to see fiscal year '17 earnings per share getting pretty close to $5 a share. If all goes well, we might hit that $5. But I would say by our modeling, I'd say we'll get up into the neighborhood. We'll get pretty close to $5. And beyond that, I'm going to -- gross margin and OpEx, that mix will depend on the type of business and opportunities we have as we go through the year. And I'll add I think tax rate should be about 10%, and next quarter, we expect shares to be about 133 million, and we'll see what we do from there on.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if I -- also, Eric, it sounds like China's picking up for you guys in Q2. I wonder if you're already starting to see some progress that you had planning on making at MediaTek. And then just also, if you could just clarify, I know you said
componenttext: Great. And then if I -- also, Eric, it sounds like China's picking up for you guys in Q2. I wonder if you're already starting to see some progress that you had planning on making at MediaTek. And then just also, if you could just clarify, I know you said growing in Q2, but was China up or down for you guys in Q1 as well?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Mike. No question, we're much happy with our position at MediaTek now than we were 6 to 9 months ago. We announced in Barcelona the RF Flex GEN-3 solutions, which are aligned with both MediaTek and Qualcomm, frankly, and seeing a pretty good
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Mike. No question, we're much happy with our position at MediaTek now than we were 6 to 9 months ago. We announced in Barcelona the RF Flex GEN-3 solutions, which are aligned with both MediaTek and Qualcomm, frankly, and seeing a pretty good uptake. We saw -- exiting the March quarter, we began to see China really take off. So they were okay in March, but they weren't really the factor that helped offset seasonality as much as Samsung was.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I will also point out, as we touched on last quarter, we kind of let you guys know that we felt that the antenna tuners and a lot of those solutions because of the metal cases starting to proliferate in our Chinese customers' designs that's a great
componenttext: Mike, I will also point out, as we touched on last quarter, we kind of let you guys know that we felt that the antenna tuners and a lot of those solutions because of the metal cases starting to proliferate in our Chinese customers' designs that's a great opportunity for growth for us. So not just the power amplifiers. It's also our high-performance BAW filters as well as some of our antenna tuners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Harsh Kumar from Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from Harsh Kumar from Stephens.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question, Bob, for you. As you look in the back half of the quarter, you've given the June guide. Steve's kind of talked about the EPS for the year. As you look in the back half of the calendar year, how do you see the market? And then I've got a follow
componenttext: A question, Bob, for you. As you look in the back half of the quarter, you've given the June guide. Steve's kind of talked about the EPS for the year. As you look in the back half of the calendar year, how do you see the market? And then I've got a follow-up.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the market goes, we're modeling pretty much flat handset growth. We're expecting people to continue to migrate up into the performance phones and as well as the marquee phones, and driving the dollar content will continue to increase. So we stil
componenttext: As far as the market goes, we're modeling pretty much flat handset growth. We're expecting people to continue to migrate up into the performance phones and as well as the marquee phones, and driving the dollar content will continue to increase. So we still expect the RF TAM for the Mobile business to grow 10% to 15%. We've repositioned James' business to start to get into double-digit growth rates, so the coming back of the infrastructure. We are expecting a pretty solid year as we go forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to add. One of the exciting things in our business is the migration of the IDP business from kind of a high single-digit growth rate to a mid-teens growth rate, comparable to what we see in the Mobile space. And this acquisition of GreenPeak i
componenttext: I just want to add. One of the exciting things in our business is the migration of the IDP business from kind of a high single-digit growth rate to a mid-teens growth rate, comparable to what we see in the Mobile space. And this acquisition of GreenPeak is one more step in that direction.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then -- Steve, I think you touched on it just very briefly. Were there -- I think you were supposed to have a major event with your cost-reduction strategy with your move to China. I was wondering if we could get a small update on that as it r
componenttext: Got it. And then -- Steve, I think you touched on it just very briefly. Were there -- I think you were supposed to have a major event with your cost-reduction strategy with your move to China. I was wondering if we could get a small update on that as it relates to what's going on there.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. Most of the action is in the second half of the calendar year, as we can't really move parts that are in production. Our customers require us to start new parts in the location of manufacture. And so that means we're intersecting with majo
componenttext: Sure, happy to. Most of the action is in the second half of the calendar year, as we can't really move parts that are in production. Our customers require us to start new parts in the location of manufacture. And so that means we're intersecting with major product launches that, as typical, happen in the back half of the calendar year. So that's when we'll start to see the flow of savings at the level we expect. So you'll see a little bit of the benefit this calendar year, and you'll see all of the benefit next calendar year. And we are on track for the second $75 million installment of our synergy expectations.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from Edward Snyder from Charter Equity Research.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, there was a long list of products groups that are now using BAW, everything from diversity modules, SAW and all-in-ones like Fusion. Does that impact...
componenttext: Eric, there was a long list of products groups that are now using BAW, everything from diversity modules, SAW and all-in-ones like Fusion. Does that impact...

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you speak up a little bit, Ed. It's hard to hear you. I know it's hard to believe, but we've...
componenttext: Can you speak up a little bit, Ed. It's hard to hear you. I know it's hard to believe, but we've...

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I could. Let me speak normal voice now. Check. Can you hear me now? You asked for it, okay. So Eric, so there's the long list of product groups now using BAW, everything from diversity, I guess, to all-in-ones like Fusion. Did that impact your mix en
componenttext: Yes, I could. Let me speak normal voice now. Check. Can you hear me now? You asked for it, okay. So Eric, so there's the long list of product groups now using BAW, everything from diversity, I guess, to all-in-ones like Fusion. Did that impact your mix enough in mobile to drive growth and operating margins? And do you expect that to occur or accelerate as they move through the year? And then, Steve, you've touched on there the PAD facility in China. Has much or any of TriQuint product lines were there -- I guess, it's mostly new Qorvo product lines because you can't move old ones back there.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly. Exactly.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What percentage are you in terms of moving to the PAD facility at this stage? Then I have one for James.
componenttext: What percentage are you in terms of moving to the PAD facility at this stage? Then I have one for James.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer yours first. I'd say we're under 50% right now and maybe closer to 25%. So it's a relatively modest portion just because of the lead times to equip the factory, start the prototypes, intersect with customer product launches. So the vast majori
componenttext: I'll answer yours first. I'd say we're under 50% right now and maybe closer to 25%. So it's a relatively modest portion just because of the lead times to equip the factory, start the prototypes, intersect with customer product launches. So the vast majority of it will be second half of the calendar year.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to the first, part A, B and C of your question, the BAW product portfolio has filled out very nicely, as you said. And we are shipping, in addition to the diversity receive modules now with BAW in it, several RF Fusion modules with BAW. And as you kno
componenttext: And to the first, part A, B and C of your question, the BAW product portfolio has filled out very nicely, as you said. And we are shipping, in addition to the diversity receive modules now with BAW in it, several RF Fusion modules with BAW. And as you know, we released our first quadplexer for the China CA market also BAW-based. And traction in all of those has been very strong in March and continuing on into June and certainly driving part of our growth. And as we talked about, the gross margins on those are above our average, so that supports the expansion in gross margin. But of course, the growth being driven by that also helps the operating margin, to your point.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, James, most of -- there's a good -- nice uptick in your business this quarter. Was it most all 4G base stations? And was that spread evenly across your customers? Did you see more of BAW [ph] had strength in certain areas?
componenttext: Okay. And then, James, most of -- there's a good -- nice uptick in your business this quarter. Was it most all 4G base stations? And was that spread evenly across your customers? Did you see more of BAW [ph] had strength in certain areas?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had good growth in the wireless infrastructure, our base station business and also in connectivity. As far as the base station side, it was really broad based across the regions and across all of our top-tier customers in the space.
componenttext: We had good growth in the wireless infrastructure, our base station business and also in connectivity. As far as the base station side, it was really broad based across the regions and across all of our top-tier customers in the space.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Quinn Bolton from Needham.
componenttext: The next question comes from Quinn Bolton from Needham.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could just comment about inventory levels at your largest customer. It seems like they've obviously seen a lower-than-expected demand. And I'm just wondering, do you think that, that supply chain here as you come out of March, looking
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could just comment about inventory levels at your largest customer. It seems like they've obviously seen a lower-than-expected demand. And I'm just wondering, do you think that, that supply chain here as you come out of March, looking into June, is fairly clean? Or do you think that there's excess component inventory that you may have shipped in previous quarters that still needs to be worked off? And then I've got a follow-up for Eric.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think you're going to like my answer, but I think things are fine. We're in pretty good shape there. So not really much to add. I mean, things look fine to us.
componenttext: Well, I don't think you're going to like my answer, but I think things are fine. We're in pretty good shape there. So not really much to add. I mean, things look fine to us.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The channel looks pretty clean from your perspective, it sounds like?
componenttext: The channel looks pretty clean from your perspective, it sounds like?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you know, and I'm sure you remember, we kind of took the medicine in the December quarter in terms of lowered expectations for that particular customer's business.
componenttext: And you know, and I'm sure you remember, we kind of took the medicine in the December quarter in terms of lowered expectations for that particular customer's business.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right. Okay, great. And then for Eric, just obviously very strong growth in China here looking into the June quarter. Wondering if you can give us some sense -- obviously, you're ramping GEN-3 of RF Flex, but you also shipped some of the premium fi
componenttext: Right, right. Okay, great. And then for Eric, just obviously very strong growth in China here looking into the June quarter. Wondering if you can give us some sense -- obviously, you're ramping GEN-3 of RF Flex, but you also shipped some of the premium filters. Can you give us some sense, is it fairly well balanced between RF Flex and filters? Or is one of those businesses much larger than the other? And then sort of a follow-on question to that is, last year, you guys saw a massive June quarter in China, and you ended up waiting for some inventory accumulation that affected September, December. As you look forward right now, do you think that, that strength in China sort of continues in the back half of the year? Or is it hard to have visibility that far out right now?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question. It's -- the -- for the portfolio, it's growing in June, in China particular, is very, very diverse; in addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the -- most of the C
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question. It's -- the -- for the portfolio, it's growing in June, in China particular, is very, very diverse; in addition to all the RF Flex and quadplexers and discrete filters and so forth that we're growing with the -- most of the China suppliers. When we look at Huawei, that's a completely different sort of dynamic. We also see them growing strongly in June but based more on the RF Fusion portfolio, some of them more premium solutions and power management and so forth. So really, I think it's fair to say our entire product portfolio is involved in one way or the other with various tiers and manufacturers throughout China. You have to remember, of course, even below Huawei, the other suppliers, the other leading suppliers like OPPO, vivo and Xiaomi, we have very good long-term relationships with these guys. And they're looking to expand beyond just domestic consumption and export more, which is driving the need for more premium filters and more bands in their phones. And so that just plays right into where we're investing. And then regarding your second point, yes, a very good point. Last year, we also had a very strong start to June. I think that has caused us to be pretty cautious. We are being just as careful as we can to make sure we're looking at the total demand and watching for customers that might be double ordering or chasing the same slots and so forth. So we're watching that really carefully. I think another big part of last year was the MediaTek Phase 2 generation, where we were, frankly, behind by 1 or 2 quarters. And it was hard to catch up once we got there. And that's -- so this transition this time with Phase 3 and then looking into Phase 5 and Phase 6, at this time we look very, very well aligned with MediaTek as well as the end customers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.
componenttext: The next question comes from Cody Acree from Drexel.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the BAW filter capacity, with Skyworks now pretty openly talking about having BAW filters in 2017 and then, of course, with them expanding their TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansi
componenttext: On the BAW filter capacity, with Skyworks now pretty openly talking about having BAW filters in 2017 and then, of course, with them expanding their TC-SAW capacity, how do you see them changing the competitive landscape and especially with all the expansion in filter capacity you've done yourself?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity it's going to take. We're moving to 8 inch. The performance keeps improving g
componenttext: As far as BAW filters go, I don't believe we see that changing the dynamic there. I think they're underestimating what it's going to take, I think the amount of IP, the capacity it's going to take. We're moving to 8 inch. The performance keeps improving generation over generation. Quite honestly, I'm not sure where they're getting the technology or where they even have a factory to produce it. We currently do know of suppliers out there that are limited in their ability to use BAW filters, coupled with a SAW filter, and you pick either you want the BAW in transmit or receive. So we're certainly familiar with those things, but just don't see it. And as far as temp-comp SAW goes, high performance filters, whether they're BAW or temp-comp SAW, continue to expand and grow. They are bigger than Qorvo in temp-comp SAW. We are expanding capacity for programs that we've already won. Like I said, we migrated to 6 inch. We talked in the February call about how we qualified the 6-inch process, and we're first in the industry to do that. This quarter, in my opening comments, I talked about how we're ramping temp-comp SAW in Florida. And again, that's for programs we've already won. But we feel pretty good about the capacity we're putting in place in BAW as well as in SAW. So when I talked about SAW filters in Greensboro, that's really to in-source filters that we're buying outside, that over time that will be a margin improvement as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one for Eric. Eric, when you talk about major drivers like carrier aggregation or diversity receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those adoption curves? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving th
componenttext: And one for Eric. Eric, when you talk about major drivers like carrier aggregation or diversity receive, can you talk about where we are in some of those adoption curves? How much of the dollar content story are those kind of major applications driving the content story? And how much of that curve we left to go?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. I would say generally we're still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to CA, which half, let's say, of the 4G phones overall this year will have CA. And eventually, I'm confident they'll all have it ove
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. I would say generally we're still in pretty early innings overall in addition to the transition to CA, which half, let's say, of the 4G phones overall this year will have CA. And eventually, I'm confident they'll all have it over the next 3 to 5 years. In China alone as well, we think somewhere like 1/4 to 1/3 of even the Chinese 4G phones will have carrier aggregation in the downlink this year. So I think overall, we're still in fairly early innings. Remember, I think we talked about this at Analyst Day. It's a compounding effect of those with reduced number of SKUs in the handset manufacturers' pipeline that drives the complexity up dramatically. And so that overall trend as well, we definitely see our #2 or #3 customer, in particular, driving towards more of a global SKU like our largest customer does. And that also is still in the early innings of development.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, congrats on outperforming other smartphone suppliers. You talked about reference design exposure in China in places like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fus
componenttext: Yes, congrats on outperforming other smartphone suppliers. You talked about reference design exposure in China in places like MediaTek. What about trends towards captive baseband that Xiaomi and Huawei, is there any implications here on RF Flex and RF Fusion?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, when you look at the value chain, the more basebands the better, from an RF guy's perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to common -- to make the products that we're developing relatively comm
componenttext: Sure. I mean, generally speaking, when you look at the value chain, the more basebands the better, from an RF guy's perspective, right? And so we like that. And in general, we're able to common -- to make the products that we're developing relatively common in terms of platforms. And then we can make relatively minor adjustments to customize for each individual baseband platform or end customer. We don't see any of the vertical baseband guys looking to develop a completely new RF architecture, for example, right? And we're already addressing those architectures that our customers fundamentally want. So now it's only a matter of interfacing to those individual basebands, relatively straightforward thing to do. And we're happy to do it, doing very, very well with all the internal vertical suppliers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so a bit of a neutral. And then my follow-up is, really nice June quarter guidance of $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall-through. I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back? Or are the
componenttext: Okay, so a bit of a neutral. And then my follow-up is, really nice June quarter guidance of $50 million of new revenues, flat gross margins. Just wondering about the earnings fall-through. I mean, is it really variable compensation coming back? Or are there some other factors getting to the EPS guidance?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question. We do expect variable comp to come back. That will lead to OpEx in the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see kind of a c
componenttext: Yes, good question. We do expect variable comp to come back. That will lead to OpEx in the low 150s kind of range, maybe the mid 150s, depending on the magnitude. It's unusual that we did not pay over the last 6-month period. And so you do see kind of a contrast there, and I want to make it clear to folks to expect that. Otherwise, we did improve gross margins sequentially. A lot of that was due to yield differences. And then you have a bit more mobile in the mix typically in the June quarter. So all that leads to a guide of 50% gross margin.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Blayne Curtis from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question comes from Blayne Curtis from Barclays.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about your China customers up in June. Maybe you could just talk about trends of your 2 largest customers, what you're embedding into that June guidance. And then, Steve, I just wanted to follow up on the OpEx. You said put GreenPeak in S
componenttext: You talked a lot about your China customers up in June. Maybe you could just talk about trends of your 2 largest customers, what you're embedding into that June guidance. And then, Steve, I just wanted to follow up on the OpEx. You said put GreenPeak in September. What's the visibility to the close date? I think you said within the quarter. And any guidance as to what's the add in the September quarter? Or would you rather just leave it out?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with respect to GreenPeak, it just closed a few days ago, so we'll have some fractional impact in the quarter when we report that -- when report the results of this quarter. But from an earnings perspective, consider it de minimis either way. And
componenttext: Yes. So with respect to GreenPeak, it just closed a few days ago, so we'll have some fractional impact in the quarter when we report that -- when report the results of this quarter. But from an earnings perspective, consider it de minimis either way. And then you're right, I would prefer to talk about GreenPeak financially when we guide the September quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Blayne, as far as our 2 largest customers, I'm not sure you know who they are. I know you clearly know who the largest one is. So I want to be careful. We're kind of splitting hairs maybe on this. But clearly, our largest customer, we're being conserv
componenttext: And Blayne, as far as our 2 largest customers, I'm not sure you know who they are. I know you clearly know who the largest one is. So I want to be careful. We're kind of splitting hairs maybe on this. But clearly, our largest customer, we're being conservative in our guidance. We do believe down to maybe flat. We'll just see. They got some pretty good selling products that we've got nice dollar content in. So -- but down to flat for our largest. Our second largest, depending on which one of those you pick, one's going to be down slightly, and one's going to be up. So I gave you the top 3. How's that?

componenttext: Okay, great. And then second question is on the share repo. You bought back 10 million shares in March. I know that some of that is going to spill over into June from kind of how it flows through the P&L. But you said that you're only going to buy back 500,000 shares in June, which is down a lot. And that's still not even working through the $250 million that you have left on the repo. So I'm wondering why you're cranking down the repo so much in June. Is that related to the stock price? Or is there something else happening in their place [ph]?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so a couple of things. The ASR that we initiated was initiated mid-quarter of the March quarter. And so we paid Bank of America $500 million. They tendered about 10 million shares to us. And since share count for a quarter is based on the average for
componenttext: Yes, so a couple of things. The ASR that we initiated was initiated mid-quarter of the March quarter. And so we paid Bank of America $500 million. They tendered about 10 million shares to us. And since share count for a quarter is based on the average for that quarter, we get about half credit this quarter, half credit next quarter. The next point, the ASR is not finished yet. Our partner Bank of America is completing that program this quarter, and exact share count tendered will depend on the average share price that we end up with. So our estimate is we'll pick up another 0.5 million shares or so as that program comes to completion. Once that program is complete, our board will evaluate whether to proceed with a subsequent buyback utilizing the remaining $250 million previously authorized.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job at what you produced in the March quarter. First question, for Steve. On the gross margin, you're guiding flat gross margin on 7% sequential revenue growth. How should we think about your long-term target model of 55%? Has anything changed on tha
componenttext: Good job at what you produced in the March quarter. First question, for Steve. On the gross margin, you're guiding flat gross margin on 7% sequential revenue growth. How should we think about your long-term target model of 55%? Has anything changed on that? And then I have a follow-up for Eric.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think the big drivers for us getting from where we're at, which is roughly 50%, to our long-term model of 55% are really those big movers in the gross margin line we referred to earlier. Moving BAW filters from 6-inch wafers to 8-inch wafers, SA
componenttext: Yes, so I think the big drivers for us getting from where we're at, which is roughly 50%, to our long-term model of 55% are really those big movers in the gross margin line we referred to earlier. Moving BAW filters from 6-inch wafers to 8-inch wafers, SAW and TC-SAW from 4 inch to 6 inch, both of those have an effect of taking roughly 1/3 of the cost out of the die for BAW filters and SAW and TC-SAW filters, very significant reductions. We'll be consolidating our gas production and do a single foundry over the next 1.5 years; in-sourcing assembly and test for a part of our mobile business, the part that used to be -- belonged to TriQuint. And each of these have a significant impact, which is largely going to be felt in FY '18. These will occur throughout the year, but the financial impact will be mostly in FY '18. And then we'd also simply have scale benefits of the kind of growth I referenced earlier. We have a fair amount of fixed cost, and we will see scale benefits as we continue to grow with the market, at what we expect will be a 10% to 15% rate. So I'm actually -- short term, I think we're going to fluctuate around, depending on the particulars of the quarter. But long term, these are big substantial items that don't involve new laws of physics. This is stuff we can do. We are well underway. And I think we are on track to get to the target model over time.

componenttextpreview: So yes, again, this is James. The relative size, I think that's a good estimate, but it's broken into those 4 areas in relatively size -- same size. And the growth rates that we've talked about before, probably single digits or so, high single digits in d
componenttext: So yes, again, this is James. The relative size, I think that's a good estimate, but it's broken into those 4 areas in relatively size -- same size. And the growth rates that we've talked about before, probably single digits or so, high single digits in defense. Our connectivity business or WiFi business we see growing close to that 20% range. That's what the market is doing. And those are really probably the big, big drivers in the business. I will say that with moving our portfolio around we've repositioned into really some significant high-growth areas. We've moved about 60% of the business into what we consider above-average growth markets, and those are markets that are growing in the 20% kind of range. The addition of GreenPeak really substantially helps that. GreenPeak's market is targeted to grow at about 60% between now and 2020. And so very high growth as we move into the connected home and really start to see IoT take off.

componenttext: Samsung is really not unlike the rest of our customers, Ed. componenttext: Yes. But on the highly integrated modules, Skyworks offers that too, and they've had some success. How does that look for the next 2 phones?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. That's what I was trying to address. I think we are well familiar with the content gains that we're seeing that's driving the overall industry to 10% to 15% growth because of the SKU consolidation, CMOs and so forth. So I tried to highlight at the beginning the things that we are maybe differentiated in, where we're bringing something in addition to that. Tuning is a big area across our entire customer portfolio now, and we really see that growing. And we've got a lot of leadership there in bringing new solutions. In envelop tracking power management as well, we're the only open-market solution for that, and we're seeing a lot of traction driving there. So in addition to those sentimental drivers, we think Qorvo does bring a lot of unique things as well that really helps us.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Qorvo Inc Q1 2017 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Doug DeLieto, Vice President of Investor Relations for Qorvo. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Qorvo Inc Q1 2017 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Doug DeLieto, Vice President of Investor Relations for Qorvo. Please go ahead.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Keith. Hello everyone and welcome to Qorvo's First Quarter Fiscal '17 Earnings Conference Call. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from m
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Keith. Hello everyone and welcome to Qorvo's First Quarter Fiscal '17 Earnings Conference Call. 
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as the risk factors associated with our business in our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC, because these risk factors may affect our operations and financial results. 
In today's release and on today's call, we provide both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results. We provide this supplemental information to enable investors to perform additional comparisons of operating results and to analyze financial performance without the impact of certain noncash expenses or other items that may obscure trends in our underlying performance. 
During our call, our comments and comparisons to income statement items will based primarily on non-GAAP results. For complete reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures, please refer to our earnings release issued earlier today available on our website, qorvo.com, under Investors. [Operator Instructions] 
Sitting with me today are Bob Bruggeworth, President and CEO; Mark Murphy, Chief Financial Officer; Eric Creviston, President of Qorvo's Mobile Products Group; and James Klein, President of Qorvo's Infrastructure and Defense Products Group. I'm also joined by other members of Qorvo's management team. And with that, I'll hand the call over to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to Qorvo's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Call. Revenue for the June quarter increased 4% year-over-year and 15% sequentially to approximately $698 million. Revenue was above our quarterly guidance p
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon everyone and welcome to Qorvo's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Call. 
Revenue for the June quarter increased 4% year-over-year and 15% sequentially to approximately $698 million. Revenue was above our quarterly guidance provided May 4, reflecting strength in Mobile in China, a large customer smartphone ramp and growth in IDP's broad markets. During the quarter, we saw customer demand coming stronger than expected, well within lead times and we worked hard to keep up with the demand. Our customers caught on us and the Qorvo team delivered. 
Gross margin was 48.2%, reflecting low band pad business, exceeding expectations with higher than expected cost. Also, less of an impact within the mix, early yields on high-volume quadplexers for China were below plan. In both examples, these were high-volume products. 
Operating margin was 24% and operating expenses were approximately $169 million. The sequential increase in OpEx reflected higher R&D expense, increased variable compensation expense and the addition of GreenPeak Technologies. 
The company's higher R&D expense reflects increased investment in the designers of high-performance filters, SAW and BAW process engineers and associated material costs for prototypes. During the June quarter, we completed our $500 million ASR, retiring an additional 400,000 shares. 
Qorvo's June financial performance and September guidance provide context for 2 major initiatives underway: One, leveraging our BAW filter assets; and two, establishing filter independents. We expect these initiatives to support margin expansion early next year as new customer programs ramp. 
Qorvo today is number 1 or number 2 in the majority of our growth markets and we are investing to extend our leadership. We're building a technology moat to maintain leadership where we're number 1. And where we're number 2, we're investing to advance from a challenger to the leader. 
How will we do this? First, we will leverage our BAW filters. The vast majority of our customers from newcomers to market leaders are requesting more, highly integrated solutions with even greater capabilities, including: Receive diversity modules with integrated LNAs; RF Flex modules with quadplexers; RF Fusion modules with hexaplexers; Wi-Fi fence with BAW filters; and multichip modules to support massive MIMO. 
An increasing number of these solutions contain BAW filters. And BAW filters rank first among our growth drivers. BAW filters will also deliver the highest incremental margin for Qorvo. And BAW filters are the primary driver of our long term operating model. 
To keep pace with customer demand, we're staffing up our engineering teams to complete the outfit of our Richardson fab, from 6-inch to 8-inch. We're also bringing up an 8-inch line in a recently acquired fab in Farmers Ranch, Texas. 
Today, our BAW filter utilization is below optimal but we expect that to reverse as new programs ramp next year. Demand for our first quadplexers have been robust and we continue to enjoy large customer interest in our BAW-based hexaplexer prototypes. More importantly, we have delivered hexaplexer solutions utilizing our recently released next generation BAW process and customer feedback indicates we are very competitive. 
For the premium tier, we are integrating BAW-based hexaplexers into RF Fusion. And in the performance tier, we are integrating BAW-based quadplexers. 
Second, we will achieve filter independents. We believe Qorvo's growth will rely increasingly on filters and filter-based products and we're adding high-performance filter designers and SAW and BAW process engineers to in-source all filters to improve our cost, accelerate time-to-market and deliver higher value solutions. 
Today, our largest revenue product, which is growing significantly this quarter, contains third-party SAW filters. By comparison, our RF Flex modules will integrate high-performance and lower costs internally sourced BAW filters for the first time. This will significantly enhance our product margins while creating a new competitive barrier-to-entry. 
To ensure we achieve filter independents, we are increasing from 6- to 8-inch BAW in Richardson and we're increasing from 4- to 6-inch [indiscernible] SAW in Florida. In Greensboro, we are converting our 6-inch gas capacity to 10 [indiscernible] SAW and adding a new power metal process for SAW which is another Qorvo first. Of note, Qorvo's power metal processor SAW is the final process needed in our toolbox, if you will, clearing the path for us to achieve filter independence. 
We are also moving our gas capacity from North Carolina to our organ fab and transitioning our North Carolina GaN products to Texas. In China, we're bringing up our second packaged assembly and test facility, even as these efforts add to COGS and R&D today. We expect them contributing to revenue and margin expansion related to large customer opportunities slated for 2017 and '18. 
Looking at our June quarterly performance by segment, Mobile Product revenue was approximately flat year-over-year and increased 18% sequentially to $547 million. Qorvo helped launch a number of premium and performance tier smartphones and we benefited in China from a strong market and the migration from 3 mode to 4 mode smartphones for domestic and export markets. 
We saw strong demand for our recently launched quadplexers and for our second-generation RF Flex modules which launched last year. In Wi-Fi, for handsets, we enjoyed 13% growth sequentially as we ramped our highly integrated RF Fusion for mobile Wi-Fi. 
Outside of handsets, Mobile Products grew 30% versus last quarter. Across all of Mobile Products, customer order activity strengthened throughout the June quarter with many orders placed well within lead times. Through the month of July, order activity in Mobile remained very strong. It's clear to us that the demand for broadband data continues to increase with the effect amplified for RF suppliers as content per device expands. We believe the expanding market requirements for carrier aggregation in 5G, among others, will favor our unique competitive strengths and we expect this to support strong, longer-term dynamics and improving visibility in our growth drivers. 
Only Qorvo delivers a comprehensive portfolio of filters, switches, amplifiers, PMICs, LNAs and tuners with the scale, integration capabilities and system-level expertise that supply an expanding variety of highly integrated solutions. 
In IDP, revenue grew 24% year-over-year and 6% sequentially to $151 million. We're very pleased with the performance of IDP, particularly the revenue and margin performance. 
The addition of a great franchise in GreenPeak Technologies and the achievement of another strong design win quarter. GreenPeak is growing at a rapid clip and we expect this acquisition to be accretive by the end of the year. IDP continues to reposition our product portfolio to support high-growth markets. And today, they're a highly diversified business in a $3.8 billion serviceable market. IDP currently forecasts the markets they serve will grow at a compound annual rate of 17% which nearly doubles their market by 2020 to $7 billion. 
In our infrastructure unit, we continue to see a stabilization in the China base station market and strong customer activity, especially in GaN. We enjoyed robust demand for our 3.5 gigahertz GaN [indiscernible] during the quarter and we supplied duplexers, LNAs and PAs for small cell solutions at multiple base station OEM customers. 
On the design front, our GaN PAs were selected by a major infrastructure provider for a massive MIMO active antenna system. 2 global wireless infrastructure manufacturer selected our 28 gigahertz 5G base station GaN PAs and a major infrastructure provider selected our 2.6 gigahertz PA, LNA and switch for pre-5G MIMO deployment. 
In connectivity, we saw strong momentum in CPE Wi-Fi, particularly 5 gigahertz. And we layered in GreenPeak Technologies during the quarter. GreenPeak is a recognized industry leader in ultra-low-power, short-range RF communication and they expand our customer offering very nicely to include highly integrated RF systems on a chip for the connected home and Internet of things. The markets we are targeting are growing faster than 40%. 
In transport, we began the production ramp of our -- of a quadlinear 400 GB -- 400G optimal driver for a Tier 1 telecom equipment provider. We also reached record revenue levels for our CATV hybrid products driven by the industry leaders. Both support the build out of infrastructure to keep pace with the ever increasing demand for data. 
In defense, our business was up 30% year-over-year. Most of this growth has been driven by domestic active electronically scanned array radar programs and the proliferation of gallium nitride, especially for international markets. In the defense market alone, we anticipate greater than $300 million of potential opportunities for Qorvo's GaN products. 
So from a high level, whether you're looking at IDP or Mobile Products, Qorvo is delivering breakthrough RF solutions that accelerate the delivery of broadband data and create value for our customers and our customers' customers. In IDP, we're introducing breakthrough products using highly differentiated internally developed technologies that enable our customers to introduce products at record speed and with higher levels of functionality. 
In Mobile, we're leveraging the industry's most complete product and technology portfolio with our broad scale, integration capabilities and system-level expertise to offer high-performance RF solutions with unprecedented levels of integration. 
In summary, Qorvo saw customer activity accelerate as the June quarter progress and the entire Qorvo team ran hard to satisfy that demand. In the September quarter, we continue to see strong demand and support of this year's most popular devices and we're rapidly expanding our capabilities to develop new, highly integrated solutions for large customer opportunities launching in 2017 and 2018. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's non-GAAP revenue increased 15% sequentially for the June quarter to $698 million. Mobile Products revenue increased 18% sequentially to $547 million and Infrastructure and Defense Products increased 6% sequentially to $151 million. Qo
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's non-GAAP revenue increased 15% sequentially for the June quarter to $698 million. Mobile Products revenue increased 18% sequentially to $547 million and Infrastructure and Defense Products increased 6% sequentially to $151 million. Qorvo had 3 10% customers, the largest at approximately 29% of revenue, representing the aggregated demand of multiple subcontractors for this end customer. Our other 10% customers during the quarter were Huawei and Samsung. 
Gross margin was 48.2%, impacted by low band pad business exceeding expectations with higher than expected costs. Upon transition to a more integrated modules with Qorvo produced filters and completion of our fab conversions, we expect gross margin to expand. 
Operating expenses increased to $169 million on higher R&D expenses to support ongoing development programs in premium filters, higher variable compensation expense and the addition of our GreenPeak acquisition. In the September quarter, we expect to achieve our OpEx goal of approximately 20% of sales and we expect to sustain that performance through the December quarter. 
Operating income for the June quarter was $168 million or 24% of revenue. Net income was $143 million and earnings per share was $1.08. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Total cash and short-term investments was $447 million. Cash flow from operations was $59 million, reflecting the working capital build associated with higher first quarter sales and our September quarter outlook. Capital expenditures increased to $130 million primarily to address growing premium filter demand. 
During the June quarter, we completed our $500 million ASR, retiring an additional 400,000 shares. $250 million remains available under the $1 billion program authorized last November. We continue to make progress on opportunities to improve our growth and profitability. In the quarter, we acquired GreenPeak, a producer of low-power RF devices, expanded our capabilities to serve IoT markets. Our BAW products are closing in on state-of-the-art performance and we're on a measured pace to add capacity needed to meet expected customer demand for premium filters. 
As Bob mentioned, a large number of productivity projects are underway, including conversion to 8-inch BAW [indiscernible] in our Texas fab and 6-inch SAW in our Florida fab. Conversion of our North Carolina fab to TC-SAW and SAW, consolidation of our gas capacity in Oregon, migration of GaN from North Carolina to Texas; an additional mobile products assembly and test capacity in China. 
We expect these new product capabilities, capacity additions and productivity initiatives to help us sustain above market growth and drive margin expansion. Now let's turn to our business outlook. 
Qorvo currently believes customer demand supports the following non-GAAP expectations for the September quarter. Quarterly revenue between $820 million and $850 million; gross margin of approximately 47%; diluted EPS between $1.35 and $1.45; a tax rate of approximately 10%. 
Our September quarter guidance reflects strong broad-based demand. We expect gross margins to remain near the second quarter levels through the year on low band product mix and while our fab conversions are underway. We expect OpEx to trend down through the back half of the year. We project CapEx to remain elevated as we align capacity additions with stronger customer demand for premium filters and our integrated modules. 
With that, we'll open up the call to your questions.

componenttext: Okay, thank you. I wanted to ask about gross margin. We've already started to get questions about that quite a bit. componenttext: Harsh, thanks for the question. I just want to clarify. We've got a lot of initiatives and we're working on them. So it's got a lot of content that is not internally in our fab. So we don't see the benefit of it from a contribution margin. So that does play into it. When we have our Analyst Day, we'll outline and quantify a lot of those activities to help you model next year where we can get to on the gross margin.

componenttext: Sure, Vivek. Let me start with IDP is doing very well. Their margins held in there, no problem there. The majority of Eric's business did very well. You're right, we have 1 that product. I would be candid with you, it's also not yielding fantastic. But for the most part, you're correct. It is a product related, not an industry structure issue. So I would agree with your assessment, Vivek.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, very good. And then as my follow up, when I look at the September quarter outlook, I sort of fell out of my chair when I saw the upside versus some of the street expectations. But I'm curious, is there a pull forward of demand, just because we are r
componenttext: Okay, very good. And then as my follow up, when I look at the September quarter outlook, I sort of fell out of my chair when I saw the upside versus some of the street expectations. But I'm curious, is there a pull forward of demand, just because we are reminded to last year when the industry went through a lot of turbulence. So you are nearly $120 million above street expectations. First, how much of GreenPeak out of that? And then how much is, given there's any pull forward demand and the last part of that is how to think about December quarter seasonality given that you're having such a strong September quarter?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Number 1, GreenPeak is in that $6 million, $7 million a quarter. So that's not driving all the growth. Like we said, most of the growth is coming out of Eric's business. I don't think we're seeing the pull forward. We've talked a lot about that. We s
componenttext: Yes. Number 1, GreenPeak is in that $6 million, $7 million a quarter. So that's not driving all the growth. Like we said, most of the growth is coming out of Eric's business. I don't think we're seeing the pull forward. We've talked a lot about that. We still have a lot of demand that we are running hard to keep up with given the guide we even gave. As far as December goes, let me put it another way, Vivek. I think the growth that we're seeing this quarter, as well as into December, will be how well marquee phones sell. I think our own view is China, we're tampering our outlook for the second half of the calendar year. So as we look into December, depends on, to your question, how much of the demand is pulled in that we might be able to capture. Because were all out right now. We ran very hard in the June quarter, we're running -- now we're running pretty hard, still staying through this quarter. So as we look at things today, we're not seeing a pull forward and as we look at our customer forecast and our own expectations for, in particular, China market, we could see December up.

componenttext: This is [indiscernible] Patel for Ambrish Srivastava. My first question is on the increasing R&D spending, particularly for filter designers, what drove the increasing OpEx for R&D given that you only have, it seems like a mature bond [indiscernible] product?

componenttext: Yes, we have talked many times about that portfolio shifting towards more filter-based products and we do continue to see that trend. In fact, if anything it's accelerating through all tiers of the market now. Customers are asking us to integrate at a higher level and include more filters. And Bob mentioned our drive towards filter independence. And making sure that we have the ability to design and manufacture at least the lion's share, if not all of those filters internally. So that includes regular SAW as well as TC-SAW and BAW. And so we will continue to need more R&D bandwidth to develop the processes. But then also to develop the products and integrate them in to our portfolio.

componenttext: It was, in the June quarter, it was pretty strong. And in the September quarter, we see it continuing as of now. The market is quite healthy and we are returning back to our kind of normal share that we should've been at earlier in the year already. So we're kind of seeing that compound affect probably and add it to the fact that the dollar content overall continues to grow as we see more and more 5 and 6 mode 4G phones being shipped into the market.

componenttext: Yes, I think Cody, right now, we'll give more specifics at the November Investor Day. But we see a path to above 50% gross margin. With both the trends in the business, specifically as we move to more BAW mix in the future. And then also, all the initiatives underway, which you heard about. I mean, we're in the early innings on a number of those initiatives. So within the next several quarters, those will be completed and we expect, as you know, wafer conversions, 4 to 6 and 6 to 8 provides significant benefit on throughput and then we'll be over some of the yield issues that we're having.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Cody, this Eric. It's a little tough to answer that. They can improve tremendously. The rate depends upon exactly how we get from here to there. Part of the nature of these products is that they ramp into very high volumes very rapidly. And so someti
componenttext: Hey, Cody, this Eric. It's a little tough to answer that. They can improve tremendously. The rate depends upon exactly how we get from here to there. Part of the nature of these products is that they ramp into very high volumes very rapidly. And so sometimes, by the time you realize there's a yield issue, you already have an awful lot of products in the pipeline. That's where we are here. So we can improve them over the course of several quarters, it's probably the best way to answer that.

And then obviously, with the ones where we build the RF Fusion for -- RF Flex for the Wi-Fi, that does have a better than company average margin.

componenttext: Yes. What you'll see, Mike, you'll see OpEx in the second quarter on a dollar basis, about in line with what you saw in the first quarter. But on a percent basis, we'll be down towards our long-term target, which is 20% of sales. And then you'll see OpEx on a dollar basis begin to drop off through the second half as some spending we know falls off and productivity programs continue.

componenttext: Well, again, it's primarily a single product problem. And it's a low band PAD problem where you have significant outsourced filter content. And that was a large volume product in the first quarter and it actually becomes larger in the second quarter as another low band PAD family product comes on. So that's the effect you're seeing in the first and second quarter.

componenttext: Okay, great. And as my follow up, I wanted to ask about BAW. You talked in your prepared remarks about utilization rates and your BAW business being suboptimal today. Could you maybe provide a bit more granularity here and also comment on when you expect utilization rates to be at or above optimal levels in BAW? Thank you.

componenttext: Sure, Toshiya. What I said is we were not at optimal levels today and you know we've added capacity and we're continuing to add capacity as we expand from 6 to 8 and adding 8-inch in the Farmers branch and quite honestly, it's going to be the timing of new marquee phones that we are launching in in calendar year 2017.

componenttext: And I'll just add that we're going to pace that investment as we get clarity on customer demand. We feel very good about the customer demand and the quality of our product. So we're comfortable making early commitments. But the actual construction spend, pace, will be determined by our clarity on wins.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the yield issue and as it relates to gross margin. You talked about gross margin kind of staying here through the year. Is that -- do you have a line of sight as to just the cost issue part of this? Or any other kind of color you can ha
componenttext: Just a question on the yield issue and as it relates to gross margin. You talked about gross margin kind of staying here through the year. Is that -- do you have a line of sight as to just the cost issue part of this? Or any other kind of color you can have in terms of how you maybe deem conservative or not as to kind of the recovery from this?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again, it's a little bit hard to tell the rate and pace of recovery. There are certain things that can move the needle, actually relatively quickly. We're planning on it being a longer haul, as I said a couple of quarters to fix the issue again, prim
componenttext: Yes, again, it's a little bit hard to tell the rate and pace of recovery. There are certain things that can move the needle, actually relatively quickly. We're planning on it being a longer haul, as I said a couple of quarters to fix the issue again, primarily because there's a lot of volume in the line early part of the ranch. So I think we're now well in terms of the number of parts produced. We understand the yield issue quite well. And so I don't think there's a lot of uncertainty from this point forward other than how rapidly we can implement the changes and get it through the pipeline.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then as my follow up, in terms of capital allocation with GreenPeak which is kind of tuck-in, you've been fairly aggressive buying back stock. So kind of big picture, how you view best use of cash here in terms of your own stock versus attemps
componenttext: Got it. And then as my follow up, in terms of capital allocation with GreenPeak which is kind of tuck-in, you've been fairly aggressive buying back stock. So kind of big picture, how you view best use of cash here in terms of your own stock versus attemps to diversify the business?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to take that?
componenttext: Want to take that?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. I guess I'll start with buyback. We've repurchased 1.3 billion of shares in the last 5 quarters and we have $250 million remaining on our $1 billion authorization. I'll add that we currently expect to continue buying our shares
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. I guess I'll start with buyback. We've repurchased 1.3 billion of shares in the last 5 quarters and we have $250 million remaining on our $1 billion authorization. I'll add that we currently expect to continue buying our shares under that authorization. We view -- we're interested obviously in a thoughtful capital allocation framework that will consider organic growth opportunities, including CapEx needs which we just talked about on BAW. Those are very high return projects, relatively low risk from a project execution standpoint. So those would be early priority on spend. We're always looking at acquisition opportunities that would fit well with Qorvo. But I'll add that we're not capacity constrained from a balance sheet standpoint to doing those. But there is a very high bar on the return requirements for allocation of capital to those opportunities. And then, we expect to be -- plan to be regular, steady buyers of our shares as part of this thoughtful capital allocation framework. And that's what we've done.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, you said you were surprised by the gross margin on the low band PAD coming in here and there are several comments that [indiscernible] both cost and the yield issue. Yield, I get. I suppose because you always get surprised. But can you explain what
componenttext: Eric, you said you were surprised by the gross margin on the low band PAD coming in here and there are several comments that [indiscernible] both cost and the yield issue. Yield, I get. I suppose because you always get surprised. But can you explain what happened in cost? I mean, the SAW filters, do they raise prices for you? Is it not, both pricing, what changed from the time that you did the prototype and you bid the part, won the part, to the time you started producing the part that smacked margins as hard as they were? And then as a follow up, you got a gazillion programs going on here. You're moving to 8-inch in BAW and Richardson, are you starting an 8-inch in Farmers Branch? Are you ramping in 8-inch? Meaning that it's already a running moved to 8-inch? You had 6-inch in TC-SAW in Florida. You're launching of assuming 6-inch TC in [indiscernible] North Carolina, moving GaN to Texas, moving GaAs to Oregon and a new path facility in China. Maybe you could take a few minutes and just walk through what the impact of some or all of these are on the margin issues, maybe none, maybe some, what this utilization, whatever because as I'm sure, most of the other guys in this call are getting flooded with the gross margin question before even the call started. So any of us will be.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll starting on a farmers mass on 8-inch. So we'll start with what we believe will be our lowest cost there and again, we'll qualify the line in '17 and be ready for production in '18. As far as what's going on in the packaging assembly and test facilit
componenttext: We'll starting on a farmers mass on 8-inch. So we'll start with what we believe will be our lowest cost there and again, we'll qualify the line in '17 and be ready for production in '18. As far as what's going on in the packaging assembly and test facility, again, that's one of the largest pre merger synergies that we talked about is because a lot of the legacy work is outside of assembly houses. And in fact, given the volume we're running right now, we have a lot of work on the outside and that's why they're bringing up and we had our grand opening in [indiscernible] just a few weeks ago and as we in source that, that is a significant cost saving for us. As far as, yes, in Greensboro, we're starting in 6-inch with standard SAW and 10 comp SAW its a significant margin improvement over what we're paying outside, I'll say it that way. But it will take time to get those into the market and designed into current products. So again, much more of a 2017 story than a 2016 story. And as far as the diameters and you can do the math on what the savings is from 6 to 8. We'll give you a lot more color on the timing of that at the Analyst Day. But again, most of these things really take hold in 2017. I know you had a question for Eric as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we probably can't say much about the outsource content to your question other than to say that it's a source that's clearly not a long-term viable candidate. There's so much flexibility in the near term in terms of pricing and what we can do with tha
componenttext: Yes, we probably can't say much about the outsource content to your question other than to say that it's a source that's clearly not a long-term viable candidate. There's so much flexibility in the near term in terms of pricing and what we can do with that supplier. Internally though, the yields are related to some sophistication at the end product level. But also to your point, this is the first volume to ramp a very hard in the new 6-inch TC line and we're definitely working out a lot of issues in there as well. That's contributing certainly to the issue.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on what you think your total [indiscernible] contact gains were for premium phones in this year versus last year and not a lot of SKUs but sort of a rough estimate? [indiscernible] smartphones?
