componenttext: What I do feel comfortable is we grow our dollar content. Clearly, one of our customers we grew significantly in dollar content as they release phones throughout the year. If I look at our top 3 customers, we expanded our dollar content and to your point, it really gets on the mix on SKUs. But I think in aggregate, we definitely increased our share as well as our dollar content.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just wanted to follow-up on Vivek's question around a little bit of seasonality. You talked about growing in December. Does this -- Does that growth suggest anything how it might look in to the margin if you have a pretty steep dip in t
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just wanted to follow-up on Vivek's question around a little bit of seasonality. You talked about growing in December. Does this -- Does that growth suggest anything how it might look in to the margin if you have a pretty steep dip in terms of strength is being pulled forward somewhat does this suggest a more shallow margin? Or would that sort of trend more normally?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: To be clear, I don't believe I acknowledged there's any pull forward. I said if there was, then December, it could impact December. But right now, we don't view it as demand being pulled forward. I think what -- if you look at what happened last year, I t
componenttext: To be clear, I don't believe I acknowledged there's any pull forward. I said if there was, then December, it could impact December. But right now, we don't view it as demand being pulled forward. I think what -- if you look at what happened last year, I think it's pretty widely known that some of the marquee phones didn't quite sell as well into the December quarter which impacted December and slightly into March. So I think it all does come down too, if you're asking, what December or March are going to look like, as we said, China, we seem to be getting back to our normal share levels there. So that's where the strength in the China market that we see. We see it continues to migrate from 3 mode to 5 and full mode. So that's dollar content. We think the China market is doing well. But we have a conservative view in my comments for December. And to your point, typically, margins down seasonally and I don't think that's going to change from any other year.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Chris Caso with CLSA.
componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Caso with CLSA.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question with regards to China and the comments and I think you've talked about tempering your expectations yet the revenue growth is strong. So if you maybe if you could clarify more specifically what your expectations would be for China
componenttext: Just a follow-up question with regards to China and the comments and I think you've talked about tempering your expectations yet the revenue growth is strong. So if you maybe if you could clarify more specifically what your expectations would be for China as you go into the September quarter, how much of that is dialed into your growth expectations and then perhaps into the fourth -- into the December quarter as well?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do have growth in China dialed in. That's based on actually very strong backlog at this time, in order activity and visibility into the dollar content expansions that our customers are asking for for these phones. However, the majority of the growth
componenttext: So we do have growth in China dialed in. That's based on actually very strong backlog at this time, in order activity and visibility into the dollar content expansions that our customers are asking for for these phones. However, the majority of the growth is not driven by China this quarter, it's driven by other large customers and marquee phone ramps.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as a follow, we've heard, I guess, different commentary from different folks with regard to inventory levels at customers now as you're going into the seasonally stronger period here. I guess 2 questions on that. One is, although you took
componenttext: Okay, great. And as a follow, we've heard, I guess, different commentary from different folks with regard to inventory levels at customers now as you're going into the seasonally stronger period here. I guess 2 questions on that. One is, although you took a hit from some inventory reductions back starting in last December quarter, do you think those will still persisted in the June quarter such that you were shipping below customer consumption? And at this point, as we go into the September quarter, do you think those inventory reductions are now complete?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd rather just make this comment at a very high level. Typically, we shipped in to our customers well before they start selling because they build up their inventory to go. So typically in June, we would typically be under shipping what they're sell
componenttext: Yes, I'd rather just make this comment at a very high level. Typically, we shipped in to our customers well before they start selling because they build up their inventory to go. So typically in June, we would typically be under shipping what they're selling. So what I can say, specifically about our business, we saw what was coming. We took actions in December, a little bit in March. But we were pretty much clean starting in June.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Chris, I'll add that our churns did increase about 10%. And then the -- our inventory levels did go up about $30 million. But that was, as you can see now, to prepare for September and follow-on quarter.
componenttext: Yes. And Chris, I'll add that our churns did increase about 10%. And then the -- our inventory levels did go up about $30 million. But that was, as you can see now, to prepare for September and follow-on quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question on gross margin as well. Your peer, Skyworks, guided flat margins on revenue [indiscernible] in September. You guys are guiding down gross margin. I understand there's no structural change in the pricing environment. But can you comment
componenttext: I have a question on gross margin as well. Your peer, Skyworks, guided flat margins on revenue [indiscernible] in September. You guys are guiding down gross margin. I understand there's no structural change in the pricing environment. But can you comment on may be parts of the market like low band pads which are more commoditized and if you can also help me understand why you will be chasing low band PADs if you have been stronger in the mid and high bands historically?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, for sure. I want to say quite clearly that this is not a pricing issue. I also want to take issue in saying low band PAD is a commoditized business. I do think that's the case at all. Essentially these high-performance low band PADs is a temper
componenttext: Yes, Eric, for sure. I want to say quite clearly that this is not a pricing issue. I also want to take issue in saying low band PAD is a commoditized business. I do think that's the case at all. Essentially these high-performance low band PADs is a temperature compensated trend for filters in the, these of a high performance products, there are very few people can manufacture them, is not commoditized and there's not a pricing issue going on here at all. Because they're incredibly hard to manufacture, we're having some yields ramping a new 1 and especially with again, new wafer line unit. So why were in the low band PAD business? Is actually a premium product category and we see a lot of customers now asking us and getting us the opportunity to do the entire front end. You need to have low band, mid band and high band, all of the switching and power management and so forth to be able to do that. So it's an important part of the portfolio. It's going to be a profitable part of the portfolio as well going forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And a follow, Mark. Can you talk about the full fiscal '17 CapEx expectations, full year?
componenttext: Great. And a follow, Mark. Can you talk about the full fiscal '17 CapEx expectations, full year?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're going to be about, if I recall, about 15% of sales for the year if we maintain our pace of spend. I -- just to be clear, I mentioned that if we don't have the clarity, we'll certainly slow down the spend. So I'd say I don't expect it to be any
componenttext: Yes, we're going to be about, if I recall, about 15% of sales for the year if we maintain our pace of spend. I -- just to be clear, I mentioned that if we don't have the clarity, we'll certainly slow down the spend. So I'd say I don't expect it to be any worse than about 15%.

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on that BAW capacity question. You mentioned a couple times of your call that you are not at optimal levels and I'm just wondering if you're referring to the fact that you are underutilized currently or are you guys are running full out and you need to add capacity in the near term to meet demand and I've got a follow up question.

componenttext: Sure, Quinn. We are not running at capacity. We're nowhere close to that. So I would say we're under loaded then from optimal.

componenttext: Got it. Then just coming back to the gross margin, obviously you talked a lot about the low band pad. Just wondering if you could make a few comments about sort of the China product gross margins, especially as you ramp the quadplexers, hexaplexers, is that the mobile product going into China, carrying sort of corporate or [indiscernible]  These mobile product average gross margins, is there anything you can distinguish in terms of gross margin contribution from China versus some of their premium customers?

componenttext: So there's really not a large difference. There's a wide, not a wide range, but there's a range of gross margin for the different product that's selling in China. In general, the portfolio, especially the number of products are basically line with the average number of portfolio margins.

componenttext: Yes, Blayne, the quadplexers had a larger impact in the June quarter than the low band PAD. And the low band PAD had a bigger impact, much bigger impact this quarter and the quadplexers, we've taken some actions and made some progress.

componenttext: That's good. And just a follow up, in terms of the yield issues, as that impacted any delivery dates or what's your lead time? componenttext: Pretty detailed question. So yes, I would say yield issues of course, we are working through those and ensuring our continuation of the supply. But of course, we coordinate with our customers but these are things that can happen relatively quickly.

Does that create more filter pricing pressure? What's your thoughts there?

componenttext: I'm not sure I fully understood the question on...

componenttext: I'm just wondering as you pull your filters in house and there's obviously more excess filters in the supply chain, does that increase pricing pressure on the filter, on the filter side?

componenttext: Yes, sorry, I guess, we're having a hard time why pulling the filters inside will create excess inventory of filters and create pricing pressure. Will go the opposite way, I think.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it -- as far as 8 inch BAW filters go, is going to be a very low percentage. That's what we are converting to this year and again, as I said, bring up to farmers branch. And in SAW filters, as we continue to expand in Florida as well as bringing up t
componenttext: Yes, it -- as far as 8 inch BAW filters go, is going to be a very low percentage. That's what we are converting to this year and again, as I said, bring up to farmers branch. And in SAW filters, as we continue to expand in Florida as well as bringing up the North Carolina facility, that mix will start to move to 6 inch and a much larger percentage. And don't have the percentage off the top of my head again. We'll give you out at Analyst Day. But it will be a larger percentage than 6-inch.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned GaAs moving to Oregon. Bob, you will be consolidating all GaAs fab in Oregon? Or will you be splitting gas in Oregon and North Carolina? And then [indiscernible]  TC-SAW, first one to actually produce the filters years ago I know one of your
componenttext: You mentioned GaAs moving to Oregon. Bob, you will be consolidating all GaAs fab in Oregon? Or will you be splitting gas in Oregon and North Carolina? And then [indiscernible]  TC-SAW, first one to actually produce the filters years ago I know one of your competitors to kind of leap frog you in modules, to your largest customers. So they are larger TC-SAW. But I'm not surprised you promise the TC-SAW is that the new process, a new part given your legacy and how long you've been in this technology, what's changed there that made us more difficult part, just a filter SAW, get the module.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ed, we're transitioning over time. Our Greenboro gallium arsenide as well as GaN will be focused on filters. And as far as the temp comp saw.
componenttext: So Ed, we're transitioning over time. Our Greenboro gallium arsenide as well as GaN will be focused on filters. And as far as the temp comp saw.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you had on it early. We're doing a lot right now, including adding factories, Florida and Greensboro then also going from 4-inch to 6-inch and managing issues of wafer breakage as well as parameter distribution and as you really run more and more
componenttext: I think you had on it early. We're doing a lot right now, including adding factories, Florida and Greensboro then also going from 4-inch to 6-inch and managing issues of wafer breakage as well as parameter distribution and as you really run more and more wafers to the new 6-inch line, you get to see the full description. Also, I think the records at the end module are tougher, generation over generation, the requirement are getting harder. Dialing in the specification us at a very fine level is the issue.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I know you mentioned it, Bob, to buy parts on the outside market like you're doing now because everybody outsources SAW at this point even your competitors, you're buying a package part from that which is large, more expensive, et cetera. Would
componenttext: Right. And I know you mentioned it, Bob, to buy parts on the outside market like you're doing now because everybody outsources SAW at this point even your competitors, you're buying a package part from that which is large, more expensive, et cetera. Would you go internally, you'll be away for skilled packaging, should we expect and I don't know the mix but I'm expecting you've seen quite of that product in some of your modules, low band pad. Should we expect to see significant improvement in gross margin given the fact that one, you're producing and two, it's going to be smaller and more efficient part than what you can buy in outside market ready and just if you could, may be give us some idea the timing when you think you'll be independent in SAW?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe big picture, you'll, certainly on the right track. You're absolutely expect that we can insource these filters ourselves in our new larger factories that are well utilized, we will definitely see improvements in gross margin. And this is a multi
componenttext: So maybe big picture, you'll, certainly on the right track. You're absolutely expect that we can insource these filters ourselves in our new larger factories that are well utilized, we will definitely see improvements in gross margin. And this is a multi generational thing. This cannot happen overnight to completely eliminate outsourcing of the filters. We're starting on it. We're adding the capacity, adding the filter designers to be able to do it. It will take 2 or 3 product cycles to get there.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And ladies and gentlemen, this will conclude our Q&A portion of the call. I will turn it to management for closing remarks.
componenttext: And ladies and gentlemen, this will conclude our Q&A portion of the call. I will turn it to management for closing remarks.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As always, we thank you for joining us tonight. Qorvo's a leading participant in large, healthy markets with unique competitive strengths and improving visibility into macro trends and large customer programs driving our growth. We anticipate strong deman
componenttext: As always, we thank you for joining us tonight. Qorvo's a leading participant in large, healthy markets with unique competitive strengths and improving visibility into macro trends and large customer programs driving our growth. We anticipate strong demand in support of today's most popular devices and we're expanding our capabilities to develop new, highly integrated solutions for large customer opportunities, launching in 2017 and 2018. Thank you.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Qorvo, Inc. Q1 2017 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Doug DeLieto, Vice President, Investor Relations for Qorvo. Please go ahead.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Qorvo, Inc. Q1 2017 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Doug DeLieto, Vice President, Investor Relations for Qorvo. Please go ahead.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Keith. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's First Quarter Fiscal '17 Earnings Conference Call.This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Keith. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's First Quarter Fiscal '17 Earnings Conference Call.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as the risk factors associated with our business in our annual report on Form 10-K filed with the SEC because these risk factors may affect our operations and financial results.
In today's release and on today's call, we provide both GAAP and non-GAAP financial results. We provide this supplemental information to enable investors to perform additional comparisons of operating results and to analyze financial performance without the impact of certain noncash expenses or other items that may obscure trends in our underlying performance.
During our call, our comments and comparisons to income statement items will be based primarily on non-GAAP results. For complete reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial measures, please refer to our earnings release issued earlier today available on our website, qorvo.com, under Investors. [Operator Instructions]
Sitting with me today are Bob Bruggeworth, President and CEO; Mark Murphy, Chief Financial Officer; Eric Creviston, President of Qorvo's Mobile Products Group; and James Klein, President of Qorvo's Infrastructure and Defense Products Group. I'm also joined by other members of Qorvo's management team.
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Bob.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Call.Revenue for the June quarter increased 4% year-over-year and 15% sequentially to approximately $698 million. Revenue was above our quarterly guidance
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Qorvo's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Call.
Revenue for the June quarter increased 4% year-over-year and 15% sequentially to approximately $698 million. Revenue was above our quarterly guidance provided May 4, reflecting strength in Mobile in China, a large customer smartphone ramp and growth in IDP's broad markets. During the quarter, we saw customer demand come in stronger than expected, well within lead times, and we worked hard to keep up with the demand. Our customers called on us, and the Qorvo team delivered.
Gross margin was 48.2%, reflecting low-band PAD business exceeding expectations with higher-than-expected cost. Also, less of an impact, but in the mix, early yields on high-volume quadplexers for China were below plan. In both examples, these were high-volume products.
Operating margin was 24%, and operating expenses were approximately $169 million. The sequential increase in OpEx reflected higher R&D expense, increased variable compensation expense and the addition of GreenPeak Technologies.
The company's higher R&D expense reflects increased investment in the designers of high-performance filters, SAW and BAW process engineers and associated material cost for prototypes. During the June quarter, we completed our $500 million ASR, retiring an additional 400,000 shares.
Qorvo's June financial performance and September guidance provide context for 2 major initiatives underway: one, leveraging our BAW filter assets; and two, establishing filter independents. We expect these initiatives to support margin expansion early next year as new customer programs ramp.
Qorvo today is #1 or #2 in the majority of our growth markets, and we are investing to extend our leadership. We are building a technology moat to maintain leadership where we're #1. And where we're #2, we're investing to advance from a challenger to the leader.
How will we do this? First, we will leverage our BAW filters. The vast majority of our customers from newcomers to market leaders are requesting more highly integrated solutions with even greater capabilities, including receive diversity modules with integrated LNAs; RF Flex modules with quadplexers; RF Fusion modules with hexaplexers; Wi-Fi FEMs with BAW filters; and multichip modules to support massive MIMO. 
An increasing number of these solutions contain BAW filters. And BAW filters rank first among our growth drivers. BAW filters will also deliver the highest incremental margin for Qorvo. And BAW filters are a primary driver of our long-term operating model.
To keep pace with customer demand, we're staffing up our engineering teams to complete the upfit of our Richardson fab from 6-inch to 8-inch. We're also bringing up an 8-inch line in our recently acquired fab in Farmers Branch, Texas.
Today, our BAW filter utilization is below optimal, but we expect that to reverse as new programs ramp next year. Demand for our first quadplexers has been robust, and we continue to enjoy large customer interest in our BAW-based hexaplexer prototypes. More importantly, we have delivered hexaplexer solutions utilizing our recently released next-generation BAW process, and customer feedback indicates we are very competitive.
For the premium tier, we are integrating BAW-based hexaplexers into RF Fusion. And in the performance tier, we are integrating BAW-based quadplexers.
Second, we will achieve filter independents. We believe Qorvo's growth will rely increasingly on filters and filter-based products, and we're adding high-performance filter designers and SAW and BAW process engineers to in-source all filters to improve our cost, accelerate time to market and deliver higher-value solutions.
Today, our largest revenue product, which is growing significantly this quarter, contains third-party SAW filters. By comparison, our RF Flex modules next year will integrate high-performance and lower cost internally sourced Qorvo filters for the first time. This will significantly enhance our product margins while creating a new competitive barrier to entry.
To ensure we achieve filter independents, we are increasing from 6- to 8-inch BAW in Richardson and we're increasing from 4- to 6-inch SAW -- temp comp SAW in Florida. In Greensboro, we're converting our 6-inch gas capacity to temp comp SAW and adding a new power metal process for SAW, which is another Qorvo first. Of note, Qorvo's power metal processor SAW is the final process needed in our toolbox, if you will, clearing the path for us to achieve filter independence.
We're also moving our gas capacity from North Carolina to our Oregon fab and transitioning our North Carolina GaN products to Texas. In China, we're bringing up our second package, assembly and test facility. Even as these efforts add to COGS and R&D today, we expect them contributing to revenue and margin expansion related to large customer opportunities slated for 2017 and '18.
Looking at our June quarterly performance by segment. Mobile Product revenue was approximately flat year-over-year and increased 18% sequentially to $547 million. Qorvo helped launch a number of premium and performance-tier smartphones, and we benefited in China from a strong market and the migration from 3-mode to 4-mode smartphones for domestic and export markets.
We saw strong demand for our recently launched quadplexers and for our second-generation RF Flex modules, which launched last year. In Wi-Fi, for handsets, we enjoyed 13% growth sequentially as we ramped our highly integrated RF Fusion for mobile Wi-Fi.
Outside of handsets, Mobile Products grew 30% versus last quarter. Across all of Mobile Products, customer order activity strengthened throughout the June quarter with many orders placed well within lead times. Through the month of July, order activity in Mobile remained very strong. It's clear to us the demand for broadband data continues to increase with the effect amplified for RF suppliers as content per device expands. We believe the expanding market requirements for carrier aggregation and 5G, among others, will favor our unique competitive strengths. And we expect this to support strong, longer-term dynamics and improving visibility in our growth drivers.
Only Qorvo delivers a comprehensive portfolio of filters, switches, amplifiers, PMICs, LNAs and tuners with the scale, integration capabilities and system-level expertise to supply an expanding variety of highly integrated solutions.
In IDP, revenue grew 24% year-over-year and 6% sequentially to $151 million. We're very pleased with the performance of IDP, particularly the revenue and margin performance, the addition of a great franchise in GreenPeak Technologies and the achievement of another strong design win quarter. GreenPeak is growing at a rapid clip, and we expect this acquisition to be accretive by the end of the year. IDP continues to reposition our product portfolio to support high-growth markets. And today, they're a highly diversified business in a $3.8 billion serviceable market. IDP currently forecasts the markets they serve will grow at a compound annual rate of 17%, which nearly doubles their market by 2020 to $7 billion.
In our infrastructure unit, we continue to see a stabilization in the China base station market and strong customer activity, especially in GaN. We enjoyed robust demand for our 3.5 gigahertz GaN PAs during the quarter, and we supplied duplexers, LNAs and PAs for small cell solutions at multiple base station OEM customers.
On the design front, our GaN PAs were selected by a major infrastructure provider for a massive MIMO active antenna system. Two global wireless infrastructure manufacturers selected our 28 gigahertz 5G base station GaN PAs, and a major infrastructure provider selected our 2.6 gigahertz PA, LNA and switch for pre-5G MIMO deployment.
In connectivity, we saw strong momentum in CPE Wi-Fi, particularly 5 gigahertz. And we layered in GreenPeak Technologies during the quarter. GreenPeak is a recognized industry leader in ultra-low-power, short-range RF communication. And they expand our customer offering very nicely to include highly integrated RF systems on a chip for the connected home and Internet of Things. The markets we are targeting are growing faster than 40%.
In transport, we began the production ramp of our -- of a quadlinear 400 gig -- 400G optical driver for a Tier 1 telecom equipment provider. We also reached record revenue levels for our CATV hybrid products driven by the industry leaders. Both support the build-out of infrastructure to keep pace with the ever-increasing demand for data.
In defense, our business was up 30% year-over-year. Most of this growth has been driven by domestic, active, electronically scanned array -- radar programs and the proliferation of gallium nitride, especially for international markets. In the defense market alone, we anticipate greater than $300 million of potential opportunities for Qorvo's GaN products.
So from a high level, whether you're looking at IDP or Mobile Products, Qorvo is delivering breakthrough RF solutions that accelerate the delivery of broadband data and create value for our customers and our customers' customers. In IDP, we're introducing breakthrough products using highly differentiated internally developed technologies that enable our customers to introduce products at record speed and with higher levels of functionality.
In Mobile, we're leveraging the industry's most complete product and technology portfolio with our broad scale, integration capabilities and system-level expertise to offer high-performance RF solutions with unprecedented levels of integration.
In summary, Qorvo saw customer order activity accelerate as the June quarter progressed, and the entire Qorvo team ran hard to satisfy that demand. In the September quarter, we continue to see strong demand and support of this year's most popular devices, and we're rapidly expanding our capabilities to develop new, highly integrated solutions for large customer opportunities launching in 2017 and 2018.
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's non-GAAP revenue increased 15% sequentially for the June quarter to $698 million. Mobile Products revenue increased 18% sequentially to $547 million, and Infrastructure and Defense Products increased 6% sequentially to $151 million. Q
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Qorvo's non-GAAP revenue increased 15% sequentially for the June quarter to $698 million. Mobile Products revenue increased 18% sequentially to $547 million, and Infrastructure and Defense Products increased 6% sequentially to $151 million. Qorvo had 3 10% customers, the largest at approximately 29% of revenue, representing the aggregated demand of multiple subcontractors for this end customer. Our other 10% customers during the quarter were Huawei and Samsung.
Gross margin was 48.2%, impacted by low-band PAD business exceeding expectations with higher-than-expected cost. Upon transition to a more integrated modules with Qorvo-produced filters and completion of our fab conversions, we expect gross margin to expand.
Operating expenses increased to $169 million on higher R&D expenses to support ongoing development programs in premium filters, higher variable compensation expense and the addition of our GreenPeak acquisition. In the September quarter, we expect to achieve our OpEx goal of approximately 20% of sales, and we expect to sustain that performance through the December quarter.
Operating income for the June quarter was $168 million or 24% of revenue. Net income was $143 million and earnings per share was $1.08.
Turning to the balance sheet. Total cash and short-term investments was $447 million. Cash flow from operations was $59 million, reflecting the working capital build associated with higher first quarter sales and our September quarter outlook. Capital expenditures increased to $130 million primarily to address growing premium filter demand.
During the June quarter, we completed our $500 million ASR, retiring an additional 400,000 shares. $250 million remains available under the $1 billion program authorized last November. We continue to make progress on opportunities to improve our growth and profitability. In the quarter, we acquired GreenPeak, a producer of low-power RF devices, expanded our capabilities to serve IoT markets. Our BAW products are closing in on state-of-the-art performance, and we're on a measured pace to add capacity needed to meet expected customer demand for premium filters.
As Bob mentioned, a large number of productivity projects are underway, including conversion to 8-inch BAW wafers in our Texas fab and 6-inch SAW in our Florida fab, conversion of our North Carolina fab to TC-SAW and SAW, consolidation of our gas capacity in Oregon, migration of GaN from North Carolina to Texas and additional mobile products assembly and test capacity in China. We expect these new product capabilities, capacity additions and productivity initiatives to help us sustain above-market growth and drive margin expansion.
Now let's turn to our business outlook. Qorvo currently believes customer demand supports the following non-GAAP expectations for the September quarter: quarterly revenue between $820 million and $850 million; gross margin of approximately 47%; diluted EPS between $1.35 and $1.45; a tax rate of approximately 10%.
Our September quarter guidance reflects strong broad-based demand. We expect gross margins to remain near the second quarter level through the year on low-band product mix and while our fab conversions are underway. We expect OpEx to trend down through the back half of the year. We project CapEx to remain elevated as we align capacity additions with stronger customer demand for premium filters and our integrated modules.
With that, we'll open up the call to your questions.

componenttext: Okay. And then I wanted to ask about gross margin. We've already started to get questions about that quite a bit. So I think the, as people say in this business, "the high watermark" was somewhere around 50%, 51%, Bob. We're at 47% now. And you've got a bunch of initiatives going. And I think you mentioned in your script that it will start to reverse and go up next year. Will you be going up from a base of 46%, 47% where you're at? Or are you thinking you can possibly start to climb up from the 50s and then move up from there?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Harsh, thanks for the question. I just want to clarify. We've got a lot of initiatives and we're working on them. We have a one-product, if you will, problem today that we've got to reverse, and we'll continue to work hard to drive that. And it's kin
componenttext: Yes. Harsh, thanks for the question. I just want to clarify. We've got a lot of initiatives and we're working on them. We have a one-product, if you will, problem today that we've got to reverse, and we'll continue to work hard to drive that. And it's kind of -- it all comes down to how much of that product we sell can influence the gross margin percentage, as you can well imagine. So it's got a lot of content that is not internally in our fab. So we don't see the benefit of it from a contribution margin. So that does play into it. When we have our Analyst Day, we'll outline and quantify a lot of those activities to help you model next year where we can get to on the gross margin.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Bob, maybe just to follow up on that gross margin, I just want to clarify, the lower gross margins that you are seeing is just because you're outsourcing a certain component? So this is really a near-term company-specific issue that can be corrected? This is not the sign of some industry-wide pricing dynamic, right? I just want to get that clarified explicitly.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vivek. So let me start with IDP is doing very well. Their margins held in there. No problem there. The majority of Eric's business did very well. You're right, we have one product. I will be candid with you. It's also not yielding fantastic. But for
componenttext: Sure, Vivek. So let me start with IDP is doing very well. Their margins held in there. No problem there. The majority of Eric's business did very well. You're right, we have one product. I will be candid with you. It's also not yielding fantastic. But for the most part, you're correct. It is a product related, not an industry structure issue. So I would agree with your assessment, Vivek.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, very good. And then as my follow-up, when I look at the September quarter outlook, I sort of fell out of my chair when I saw the upside versus some of The Street expectations. But I'm curious, is there a pull forward of demand just because we are re
componenttext: Okay, very good. And then as my follow-up, when I look at the September quarter outlook, I sort of fell out of my chair when I saw the upside versus some of The Street expectations. But I'm curious, is there a pull forward of demand just because we are reminded of last year when the industry went through a lot of turbulence. So you are nearly $120 million above Street expectations. First, how much of GreenPeak out of that? And then how much is given there is any pull forward of demand? And the last part of that is how to think about December quarter seasonality given that you're having such a strong September quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Number one, GreenPeak's in that $6 million, $7 million a quarter. So that's not driving all the growth. Like we said, most of the growth is coming out of Eric's business. I don't think we're seeing the pull forward. We've talked a lot about that. We
componenttext: Yes. Number one, GreenPeak's in that $6 million, $7 million a quarter. So that's not driving all the growth. Like we said, most of the growth is coming out of Eric's business. I don't think we're seeing the pull forward. We've talked a lot about that. We still have a lot of demand that we're running hard to keep up with given the guide we even gave. As far as December goes, let me put it another way, Vivek. I think the growth that we're seeing this quarter as well as into December will be how well marquee phones sell. I think our own view is China, we're tampering our outlook for the second half of the calendar year. So as we look into December, depends on, to your question, how much of the demand is pulled in that we might be able to capture because were all out right now. We ran very hard in the June quarter. We're running -- now we're up running pretty hard still staying through this quarter. So as we look at things today, we're not seeing a pull forward. And as we look at our customer forecast and our own expectations for, in particular, China market, we could see December up.

componenttext: Sure, yes. We have talked many times about that portfolio shifting towards more filter-based products, and we do continue to see that trend, in fact, if anything, accelerating through all tiers of the market now. Customers are asking us to integrate at a higher level and include more filters. And Bob mentioned our drive towards filter independence and making sure that we have the ability to design and manufacture at least the lion's share, if not all, of those filters internally. So that includes regular SAW as well as TC-SAW and BAW. And so we will continue to need more R&D bandwidth to develop the processes but then also to develop the products and integrate them into our portfolio.

componenttext: Cody, this Eric. It's a little tough to answer that. They can improve tremendously. The rate depends upon exactly how we get from here to there. Part of the nature of these products is that they ramp into very high volumes very rapidly. And so sometimes, by the time you realize there's a yield issue, you already have an awful lot of products in the pipeline. That's where we are here. So we can improve them over the course of several quarters is probably the best way to answer that.

componenttext: We'll go next to Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also wanted to ask about gross margins just to make sure I understand you guys correctly. So in the quarter, what were some of the surprises that drove the miss in gross margins? And what's causing the leg down in the September quarter despite the huge
componenttext: I also wanted to ask about gross margins just to make sure I understand you guys correctly. So in the quarter, what were some of the surprises that drove the miss in gross margins? And what's causing the leg down in the September quarter despite the huge ramp in revenue?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you want to take that or do you want me...
componenttext: Do you want to take that or do you want me...

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, it's primarily a single-product problem. And it's a low-band PAD problem where we have significant outsourced filter content. And that was a large-volume product in the first quarter, and it actually becomes larger in the second quarter as an
componenttext: Well, again, it's primarily a single-product problem. And it's a low-band PAD problem where we have significant outsourced filter content. And that was a large-volume product in the first quarter, and it actually becomes larger in the second quarter as another low-band PAD family product comes on. So that's the effect you're seeing in the first and second quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Toshi, we expected better costs as well as our yields didn't hit where we expected to be at this point in time.
componenttext: So Toshi, we expected better costs as well as our yields didn't hit where we expected to be at this point in time.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as my follow-up, I wanted to ask about BAW. You talked in your prepared remarks about utilization rates and your BAW business being suboptimal today. Could you maybe provide a bit more granularity here and also comment on when you expect
componenttext: Okay, great. And as my follow-up, I wanted to ask about BAW. You talked in your prepared remarks about utilization rates and your BAW business being suboptimal today. Could you maybe provide a bit more granularity here and also comment on when you expect utilization rates to be at or above optimal levels in BAW?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Toshiya. What I said was we were not at optimal levels today. And we've added capacity and we're continuing to add capacity as we expand from 6 to 8 and adding 8-inch in the Farmers Branch. And quite honestly, it's going to be the timing of
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Toshiya. What I said was we were not at optimal levels today. And we've added capacity and we're continuing to add capacity as we expand from 6 to 8 and adding 8-inch in the Farmers Branch. And quite honestly, it's going to be the timing of new marquee phones that we're launching in, in calendar year 2017.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add that we're going to pace that investment as we get clarity on customer demand. We feel very good about the customer demand and the quality of our product. So we're comfortable making early commitments. But the actual construction spend p
componenttext: And I'll just add that we're going to pace that investment as we get clarity on customer demand. We feel very good about the customer demand and the quality of our product. So we're comfortable making early commitments. But the actual construction spend pace will be determined by our clarity on wins.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the yield issue and as it relates to gross margin. You talked about gross margin kind of staying here through the year. Is that -- do you have line of sight as to just the cost issue part of this? Or any other kind of color you can have
componenttext: Just a question on the yield issue and as it relates to gross margin. You talked about gross margin kind of staying here through the year. Is that -- do you have line of sight as to just the cost issue part of this? Or any other kind of color you can have in terms of how you maybe deem conservative or not as to kind of the recovery from this.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, it's a bit hard to tell the rate and pace of recovery. There are certain things that can move the needle actually relatively quickly. We're planning on it being a longer haul, as I said, a couple of quarters to fix the issue again primarily be
componenttext: Yes. Again, it's a bit hard to tell the rate and pace of recovery. There are certain things that can move the needle actually relatively quickly. We're planning on it being a longer haul, as I said, a couple of quarters to fix the issue again primarily because there's a lot of volume in the line early part of the ramp. So I think we're now well in, in terms of the number of parts produced. We understand the yield issue quite well. And so I don't think there's a lot of uncertainty from this point forward other than how rapidly we can implement the changes and get it through the pipeline.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then as my follow-up, in terms of capital allocation you did with GreenPeak, which is kind of tuck-in. You've been fairly aggressive buying back stock. So kind of big picture, how you view best use of cash here in terms of your own stock versu
componenttext: Got it. And then as my follow-up, in terms of capital allocation you did with GreenPeak, which is kind of tuck-in. You've been fairly aggressive buying back stock. So kind of big picture, how you view best use of cash here in terms of your own stock versus attempts to diversify the business.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Mark, do you want to take that?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. I guess I'll start with buyback. We've repurchased 1.3 billion of shares in the last 5 quarters, and we have $250 million remaining on our $1 billion authorization. I'll add that we currently expect to continue buying our shares
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. I guess I'll start with buyback. We've repurchased 1.3 billion of shares in the last 5 quarters, and we have $250 million remaining on our $1 billion authorization. I'll add that we currently expect to continue buying our shares under that authorization. We view -- we're interested, obviously, in a thoughtful capital allocation framework that will consider organic growth opportunities, including CapEx needs, which we just talked about on BAW. Those are very high-return projects, relatively low risk from a project execution standpoint. So those would be early priority on spend. We're always looking at acquisition opportunities that would fit well with Qorvo. But I'll add that we're not capacity constrained from a balance sheet standpoint to doing those. But there's a very high bar on the return requirements for allocation of capital to those opportunities. And then we expect to be -- plan to be regular, steady buyers of our shares as part of this thoughtful capital allocation framework. And that's what we've done.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ed Snyder with Charter Equity Research.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, you said you were surprised by the gross margin on the low-band PAD coming in here. And there are several comments that intimated both it was a cost and a yield issue. Yield, I get, I suppose because you always get surprised. But can you explain wha
componenttext: Eric, you said you were surprised by the gross margin on the low-band PAD coming in here. And there are several comments that intimated both it was a cost and a yield issue. Yield, I get, I suppose because you always get surprised. But can you explain what happened on cost? I mean, it was with the SAW filters. Did they raise prices to you? Was it not bulk pricing? What changed from the time that you did the prototype and you bid the part and won the part to the time you started producing the part that smacked margins as hard as they were? And then as a follow-up, you've got a gazillion programs going on here. You're moving to 8-inch in BAW in Richardson. Are you starting an 8-inch in Farmers Branch? Or are you ramping in 8-inch? Meaning that is it already up and running, moving to 8-inch? You had 6-inch in TC-SAW in Florida. You're launching, I'm assuming, a  6-inch TC and a SAW in North Carolina, moving GaN to Texas, moving GaAs to Oregon and a new PAD facility in China. Maybe you could take a few minutes and just walk through what the impact of some or all of these are on the margin issues, maybe none, maybe some, and whether it's utilization or whatever because as I'm sure most of the other guys on this call were getting flooded with gross margin questions even before the call started. So any help would be appreciated.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll take the easiest one. We're starting on in Farmers Branch on 8-inch. So we will start with what we believe will be our lowest cost there. And again, we'll qualify the line in '17 and be ready for production in '18. As far as what's going o
componenttext: All right. I'll take the easiest one. We're starting on in Farmers Branch on 8-inch. So we will start with what we believe will be our lowest cost there. And again, we'll qualify the line in '17 and be ready for production in '18. As far as what's going on in the packaging, assembly and test facility, again, that's one of the largest pre-merger synergies that we talked about is because a lot of the legacy work is outside assembly houses. And in fact, given the volume we're running right now, we have a lot of work on the outside, and that's why they're bringing up -- and we had our grand opening in [indiscernible] just a few weeks ago. And as we in-source that, that is a significant cost saving for us. As far as, yes, in Greensboro, we're starting in 6-inch with standard SAW and temp comp SAW. And it's a significant margin improvement over what we're paying outside. I'll say it that way. But it will take time to get those into the market and designed into current products. So again, much more of a 2017 story than a 2016 story. And as far as the diameters -- and you can do the math on what the savings is from 6 to 8. And we'll give you a lot more color on the timing of that at the Analyst Day. But again, most of these things really take hold in 2017. I know you had a question for Eric as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We probably can't say much about the outsource content, to your question, other than to say that it's a source that's clearly not a long-term viable candidate. And there's so much flexibility in the near term in terms of pricing and what we can do wi
componenttext: Yes. We probably can't say much about the outsource content, to your question, other than to say that it's a source that's clearly not a long-term viable candidate. And there's so much flexibility in the near term in terms of pricing and what we can do with that supplier. Internally though, the yields are related to some specifications at the end product level. But also to your point, this is the first volume to ramp very hard in the new 6-inch TC line, and we're definitely working out a lot of issues in there as well. That's contributing certainly to the issue.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Steve Smigie with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll go next to Steve Smigie with Raymond James.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, I was wondering if you could comment on what you think your total dollar content gains were for premium phones in this year versus last year? And I know there's a lot in terms of SKUs and stuff, but sort of a rough estimate for the flagship smartpho
componenttext: Guys, I was wondering if you could comment on what you think your total dollar content gains were for premium phones in this year versus last year? And I know there's a lot in terms of SKUs and stuff, but sort of a rough estimate for the flagship smartphones.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I do feel confident in is we grow our dollar content. Clearly, at one of our customers, as you guys know, we grew significantly more dollar content as they release phones throughout the year. If I look at our top 3 customers, we expanded our dollar c
componenttext: What I do feel confident in is we grow our dollar content. Clearly, at one of our customers, as you guys know, we grew significantly more dollar content as they release phones throughout the year. If I look at our top 3 customers, we expanded our dollar content. And to your point, it really gets down to mix on SKUs. But I think in aggregate, we definitely increased our share as well as our dollar content.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just wanted to follow up on Vivek's question a little bit around seasonality. So you talked about growing in December. Does this -- does that growth suggest anything about how it might look into March? Typically, you have a pretty steep
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just wanted to follow up on Vivek's question a little bit around seasonality. So you talked about growing in December. Does this -- does that growth suggest anything about how it might look into March? Typically, you have a pretty steep dip. And so I'm just wondering, if this is being pulled forward somewhat, does that suggest a more shallow March? Or would that sort of trend more normally?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to be clear, I don't believe I acknowledged there's any pull forward. I said if there was, then December -- it could impact December. But right now, we don't view it as demand being pulled forward. I think what -- if you look at what happened last year
componenttext: So to be clear, I don't believe I acknowledged there's any pull forward. I said if there was, then December -- it could impact December. But right now, we don't view it as demand being pulled forward. I think what -- if you look at what happened last year, and I think it's pretty widely known that some of the marquee phones didn't quite sell as well into the December quarter, which impacted December and slightly into March. So I think it all does come down to, if you're asking, what December or March are going to look like. As we said, China, we seem to be getting back to our normal share levels there. So that's the strength in the China market that we see. We see it continues to migrate from 3-mode to 5 and full mode. So that's dollar content. And we think the China market is doing well. But we have a conservative view in my comments for December. And to your point, typically, March is down seasonally, and I don't think that's going to change from any other year.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Chris Caso with CLA (sic) [ CLSA ].
componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Caso with CLA (sic) [ CLSA ].

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question with regards to China and the comments. And I think you've talked about tempering your expectations. Yet the revenue growth is strong. So if you -- maybe you could clarify more specifically what your expectations would be for Chi
componenttext: Just a follow-up question with regards to China and the comments. And I think you've talked about tempering your expectations. Yet the revenue growth is strong. So if you -- maybe you could clarify more specifically what your expectations would be for China as you go into the September quarter, how much of that is dialed into your growth expectations and then perhaps into the fourth -- into the December quarter as well.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do have growth in China dialed in. That's based on actually very strong backlog at this time and order activity and visibility into the dollar content expansions that our customers are asking for, for these phones. However, the majority of the growt
componenttext: So we do have growth in China dialed in. That's based on actually very strong backlog at this time and order activity and visibility into the dollar content expansions that our customers are asking for, for these phones. However, the majority of the growth is not driven by China this quarter. It's driven by other large customers and marquee phone ramps.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as a follow-up, we've heard, I guess, different commentary from different folks with regard to inventory levels at customers now as you're going into the seasonally stronger period here. I guess 2 questions on that. One is although you to
componenttext: Okay, great. And as a follow-up, we've heard, I guess, different commentary from different folks with regard to inventory levels at customers now as you're going into the seasonally stronger period here. I guess 2 questions on that. One is although you took a hit from some inventory reductions back -- starting in last December quarter, do you think those still persisted in the June quarter such that you were shipping below customer consumption? And at this point, as we go into the September quarter, do you think those inventory reductions are now complete?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd rather just make this comment at a very high level. Typically, we ship into our customers well before they start selling because they build up their inventory to go. So typically in June, we would typically be undershipping what they're selling.
componenttext: Yes, I'd rather just make this comment at a very high level. Typically, we ship into our customers well before they start selling because they build up their inventory to go. So typically in June, we would typically be undershipping what they're selling. So what I can say specifically about our business, we saw what was coming. We took actions in December, a little bit in March. But we were pretty much clean starting in June.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Chris, I'll add that our churns did increase about 10%. And then the -- our inventory levels did go up about $30 million. But that was, as you can see now, to prepare for the September and follow-on quarter.
componenttext: Yes. And Chris, I'll add that our churns did increase about 10%. And then the -- our inventory levels did go up about $30 million. But that was, as you can see now, to prepare for the September and follow-on quarter.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Cowen and Company.

componenttext: This is Wayne Loeb for Tim. It appears that some major smartphone makers are now second sourcing their modems. Can your comment on your relative RF share when attached to an Intel versus Qualcomm high-end beam [ph] modem?

componenttext: Yes. We've been in production for several generations now, and we do continue to see increased traction really across tiers in the market and with several baseband manufacturers.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Atif Malik with Citigroup.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question on gross margin as well. Your peer, Skyworks, guided flat margins on revenue growth in September. You guys are guiding down gross margins. I understand there's no structural change in the pricing environment. But can you comment on maybe
componenttext: I have a question on gross margin as well. Your peer, Skyworks, guided flat margins on revenue growth in September. You guys are guiding down gross margins. I understand there's no structural change in the pricing environment. But can you comment on maybe parts of the market like low-band PADs, which are more commoditized? And if you can also help me understand why you will be chasing low-band PADs if you have been stronger in the mid and high bands historically.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, go ahead, Eric.
componenttext: Yes, go ahead, Eric.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I want to say quite clearly that this is not a pricing issue. I also actually take issue in saying low-band PAD is a commoditized business. I don't think that's the case at all. It's actually these high-performance low-band PADs with temperatur
componenttext: Yes, sure. I want to say quite clearly that this is not a pricing issue. I also actually take issue in saying low-band PAD is a commoditized business. I don't think that's the case at all. It's actually these high-performance low-band PADs with temperature-compensated SAW filters in them. These are very high-performance products. Very few people can manufacture them. It's not commoditized, and there's not a pricing issue going on here at all. Because they're incredibly hard to manufacture, we're having some yields ramping a new one and especially with, again, our new wafer line in it. So why are we in the low-band PAD business? It's actually a premium product category, and we see a lot of customers now asking us and giving us the opportunity to do the entire RF front end. You need to have low band, mid band and high band, all the switching and power management and so forth to be able to do that. So it's an important part of the portfolio. It's going to be a very profitable part of the portfolio as well going forward.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And a follow-up, Mark, can you talk about the full fiscal '17 CapEx expectations, full year?
componenttext: Great. And a follow-up, Mark, can you talk about the full fiscal '17 CapEx expectations, full year?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're going to be about, if I recall, about 15% of sales for the year if we maintain our pace of spend. I -- just to be clear, I mentioned that if we don't have the clarity, we'll certainly slow down the spend. So I'd say I don't expect it to be any
componenttext: Yes. We're going to be about, if I recall, about 15% of sales for the year if we maintain our pace of spend. I -- just to be clear, I mentioned that if we don't have the clarity, we'll certainly slow down the spend. So I'd say I don't expect it to be any worse than about 15%.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Quinn with Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Quinn with Needham & Company.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on that BAW capacity question. You mentioned a couple of times on the call that you're not at optimal levels. And I'm just wondering, are you referring to the fact you're underutilized currently or you guys are running full out
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on that BAW capacity question. You mentioned a couple of times on the call that you're not at optimal levels. And I'm just wondering, are you referring to the fact you're underutilized currently or you guys are running full out and you need to add capacity in the near term to meet demand? And then I've got a follow-up question.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Quinn. It's we are not running at capacity or nowhere close to that. So I would say we're underloaded then from optimal.
componenttext: Sure, Quinn. It's we are not running at capacity or nowhere close to that. So I would say we're underloaded then from optimal.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, great. And then just coming back to the gross margin, obviously you talked a lot about the low-band PAD. I was wondering if you could make any comments about sort of the China product gross margins, especially as you ramp the quadplexers, he
componenttext: Got it. Okay, great. And then just coming back to the gross margin, obviously you talked a lot about the low-band PAD. I was wondering if you could make any comments about sort of the China product gross margins, especially as you ramp the quadplexers, hexaplexers. Is that, the mobile product going into China, carrying sort of corporate or at least mobile product average gross margins? Is there anything you can distinguish in terms of gross margin contribution from China versus some of the premium customers?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's really not a large difference. There's a wide -- not a wide range, but there's a range of gross margins for the different product types that sell into China. In general, the portfolio, especially the newer products, are basically in line with t
componenttext: So there's really not a large difference. There's a wide -- not a wide range, but there's a range of gross margins for the different product types that sell into China. In general, the portfolio, especially the newer products, are basically in line with the average mobile portfolio margins.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Just wondering here on the revenue guidance as a range of $30 million versus in the past, you gave a specific target, what some of the sensitivity there, what percent booked are you to get to the midpoint?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a change in the -- we have a great new CFO who thought that maybe we ought to be able to provide you guys with more of a range because of his experience and looking at our past performance that it's probably more prudent to do that. And I think you a
componenttext: Just a change in the -- we have a great new CFO who thought that maybe we ought to be able to provide you guys with more of a range because of his experience and looking at our past performance that it's probably more prudent to do that. And I think you also noticed one of our also competitors also gave a range. We typically gave a point. So we decided it would be good to give you the clarity there in the range. And as far as book for the quarter, between our backlog, customer forecast, things like that, we're in good shape.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good shape. Okay, great. And then just a clarification on gross margins. Low-band PADs impacted by the sourcing of filters. Sounds like you got multiple products, multiple models. I mean, can seasonality in the coming quarters ever cause a more favorable
componenttext: Good shape. Okay, great. And then just a clarification on gross margins. Low-band PADs impacted by the sourcing of filters. Sounds like you got multiple products, multiple models. I mean, can seasonality in the coming quarters ever cause a more favorable mix shift later this fiscal year? Or are we really waiting for the fiscal '18 manufacturing efficiencies and filters that come online?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This part, as you said, seasonality or sell-through of the end customers' products can definitely impact our percentage of gross margin. So absolutely.
componenttext: This part, as you said, seasonality or sell-through of the end customers' products can definitely impact our percentage of gross margin. So absolutely.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry for another gross margin one. Just wanted to clarify. So the gross margin was weaker in June. And then in September, it sounded a little bit more. It sounds like 2 issues. You have an issue on multiplexers and then you have this low-band PAD. I'm ju
componenttext: Sorry for another gross margin one. Just wanted to clarify. So the gross margin was weaker in June. And then in September, it sounded a little bit more. It sounds like 2 issues. You have an issue on multiplexers and then you have this low-band PAD. I'm just trying to understand what the impact was in both quarters, if you can quantify it, and just understand, what's the bigger driver between those 2?

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Blayne, the quadplexers had a larger impact in the June quarter than the low-band PAD. And the low-band PAD has a bigger impact, much bigger impact this quarter. And the quadplexers, we've taken some actions and made some progress.
componenttext: Yes. Blayne, the quadplexers had a larger impact in the June quarter than the low-band PAD. And the low-band PAD has a bigger impact, much bigger impact this quarter. And the quadplexers, we've taken some actions and made some progress.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good. And then just a follow-up. In terms of the yield issues, has that impacted any delivery dates? Or what's your lead time? And then in terms of fixing these issues, do these require redesigns of any of these parts, which then need to be requali

But I'm a little surprised you have the yield problems with TC-SAW. Is it a new process, a new part? Given your legacy and how long you've been in this technology, what's changed there that made this more difficult part? Just the filter SAW. Forget the module.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you hit on it earlier. We're doing a lot right now, including adding factories, Florida and Greensboro, then also going from 4-inch to 6-inch and managing issues of wafer breakage as well as parameter distributions. And as you really run more
componenttext: Yes. I think you hit on it earlier. We're doing a lot right now, including adding factories, Florida and Greensboro, then also going from 4-inch to 6-inch and managing issues of wafer breakage as well as parameter distributions. And as you really run more and more and more wafers through the new 6-inch line, you begin to see the full distribution. Also, I think the requirements at the end module are tougher. Generation over generation, the requirements are getting harder. So dialing in these specifications at a very fine level is the issue.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I know you mentioned it, Bob, but to buy parts on the outside market like you're doing now because everybody outsources SAW at this point, even your competitors, you're buying a package part from them, which is larger, more expensive, et cetera
componenttext: Right. And I know you mentioned it, Bob, but to buy parts on the outside market like you're doing now because everybody outsources SAW at this point, even your competitors, you're buying a package part from them, which is larger, more expensive, et cetera. When you go internally, it will be a wafer scaled packaging. Shouldn't we expect -- and I don't know what the mix is, but I'm expecting you're using quite a bit of that product in some of your modules, low-band PAD, maybe diversity module. shouldn't we expect to see significant improvement in gross margin given the fact that, one, you're producing it, and two, it's going to be smaller and more efficient part than what you can buy in the outside market already? And just if you could, maybe give us some idea on the timing of when you think you'll be independent in SAW.

headline: Qorvo, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe big picture, Ed, certainly you're on the right track. We absolutely expect that when we can in-source these filters ourselves in our new larger factories that are well utilized, we will definitely see improvements in gross margin. And this is a m
componenttext: So maybe big picture, Ed, certainly you're on the right track. We absolutely expect that when we can in-source these filters ourselves in our new larger factories that are well utilized, we will definitely see improvements in gross margin. And this is a multi-generational thing. This cannot happen overnight to completely eliminate outsourcing of the filters. We're starting on it. We're adding the capacity, adding the filter designers to be able to do it. It will take 2 or 3 product cycles to get there.

componenttext: As always, we thank you for joining us tonight.
